The sex is intended to arouse, the violence to excite, and the combination enables Faster Pussycat's status as an absolute masterpiece of subversion.
It's Fitzcarraldo with affirmed and not sublime biography; in essence, the same film without the pretense of fiction.
The girl's gaze of hope directs towards the viewer in the film's staggering and ambiguous final shot.
The final game in this film is a hallmark in the Brothers' oeuvre.
Like a naked body seen in fluorescent lighting, Necromania's blemishes are amplified by its cheap, unimaginative resources.
The ultimate trump of Tanner '88 is its realism.
Despite its languid, almost hypnotic pacing, The Brown Bunny is exalted with enormous suspense.
With its apparent fixation on murder and cruelty, it is difficult to overlook a number of the unsettling autobiographical details in the film.
Lone Star is intrinsically an aggregate of John Sayles' prior films, politically and racially.
Eve illustrates one of Meyer's ironies, that he's a filmmaker with unpretentious chauvinist interests, yet his primary character is an empowered female.
The scenario is keenly similar to that of the director's seminal Faster Pussycat!, only with the sex and preferred transportation of the main characters supplanted.
The principle character is an embellished creation, and serves to exaggerate peoples' intolerance - fundamentally, he is the most removed of Sayles' characters.

This dilemma between the desire not to mature and the infallibility of age is best summated in Nino Rota's score. It highlights the film's beautiful final shots and lends the final exit an air of playful hope.
Slacker is populated by new-age beatniks with neither fashion nor poetry, populating a culture that's distinguished by its lack of culture.
Lucas' bleak debut is a film markedly dissimilar from his more famous trilogy.
Although Society is at first blemished by its dated humor and contrived teenage self-discovery, we find everything is in service to a truly sensational ending.
[Hall's] performance transcends the political baggage of the film itself.
A dated although nonetheless remarkable work of propaganda.
There is a lot of music, but never too much, and the story of Beethoven's struggle with his life and genius emerges forcefully and movingly.
What is the point of all this nastiness? Well, of course, there is none.
How could such a gripping true story make such a dull film? And what was Anthony Hopkins thinking when he agreed to star?
Osmond's documentary is inspiring and emotive but it is never manipulative. The characters are working-class pragmatists and Osmond should be applauded for making no attempt to disguise this.
Winterbottom has managed to mould Brand's scatterbrain thinking and tedious, polysyllabic rhetoric into a film which, on more than a few occasions, is surprisingly thought-provoking.
This is a story that belongs on the small screen. It simply isn't interesting enough to hold the attention for 90 minutes.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This remarkable film is a tribute to the bravery of foreign correspondents and a love letter to democracy.
Time and again, Man Up is saved by Bell.

Sebastião Salgado has spent his career documenting human suffering. And yet this quiet, dignified film about the 71-year-old will leave you twitching with envy. His, truly, has been a life well-lived.
This is not a political documentary, attempting to sway one's opinion on the success or otherwise of Greenpeace. Rothwell's camera remains neutral, allowing the subjects to tell their story.
A film that does every justice to the bravery of two men who undoubtedly altered the course of the Second World War.
What should have been a shamelessly filthy stoner movie has been watered down with ill-judged, undergraduate musings on religion, philosophy and race.
Oh, how you'll laugh at the dialogue, at the plot and - most of all - at Pierce Brosnan's moustache, which is so hilarious it deserves a film of its own.

Most will find this a rather too brassy affair, handicapped by incontinent plotting. But there are probably just enough references to shape shifters, dream walkers and secret brotherhoods to keep the geeks happy.
A delightful coming-of-age tale that both celebrates young love and laments how quickly the fire of youth can be snuffed out.
It's mostly just a matter of waiting till feeding time.
If a visitor from Mars needed a crash course in sexism, this would serve.
Shot entirely on location with its child actors recruited from the streets, Salaam Bombay! enters into its subjects' lives with rare authority and absolute compassion.
The directing is sure-handed, the script intelligent, and the acting strong, especially the amazing performance from Foxx.
Hands down the best comic book franchise on film.
Vapid, lengthy, and mostly lifeless -- kind of like the desert it's named for.
A film with two opposite interpretations to its title -- figuratively sad, literally joyful.
Aside from the offensive material, The Departed fires on all cylinders as one of the best crime dramas ever made -- smart, suspenseful, and technically well made.
Doom is irritating enough to make you blow off some steam by spending a couple hours gunning down demons.
Les Choristes isn't quite as forced and syrupy as Mr. Holland's Opus or Music of the Heart, but it's not a classic like To Sir with Love or Goodbye, Mr. Chips either.
If it weren't for the clout of its two leading men, The Sentinel would be nothing more than a made-for-cable or direct-to-DVD feature.
The year's second best movie about broken and lonely people (after Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind).
A tight and engrossing mystery thriller.
It's back to the drawing board for the TV show's creators, who have previously proven themselves capable of much better than this soggy and waterlogged miscalculation.
A tighter script could have made this a classic Bible epic.
Essentially an X-files episode that wishes it were as disturbing and visually arresting as David Fincher's Seven (it's not).
Interesting and worth watching, despite the fact that complete comprehension of the film seems just beyond the reach of the viewer.
It certainly isn't as dramatic as Titanic, and the original Poseidon Adventure is still slightly better.
Enhancing the film with special effects and a clearer presentation, Lucas has turned something that was relatively unwatchable into something that can endure as a sci-fi classic.
While there are parts of Two for the Money worth watching, it's ultimately not one worth putting your money on.
There are some sequences where you will love the characters and others where you can't stand them. Hmm, maybe RV is close to the real thing after all.
Much to admire and enjoy, but what could have been a meaningful parable about individual freedoms comes off as heavy-handed politicizing that doesn't quite add up.
Like the three monsters at the center of the film, Van Helsing is a howling dog, it needs a brain, and indeed, it bites.
Without a Paddle is a sloppy effort, yet even a clichéd comedy could be fun if it actually delivered on laughs.
Ratner has met with much skepticism from fans afraid that he would botch the franchise. He actually makes this an enjoyable summer blockbuster that generally lives up to the predecessors.
Fortunately, this version gets it right. To quote another classic involving an adorable little swine, "That'll do, pig."
Neither entertaining nor exciting, the dumb and noisy Stealth will hopefully live up to its name by fading quietly from movie theaters.
Fans of movies like The Wedding Planner and You've Got Mail looking for a charming date movie with lots of laughs will fall in love with Hitch.
Naomi Watts distinguishes herself in a luminous, star-making turn as Ann -- warm, funny, charismatic, and far more than you'd expect from the damsel in distress.
The real reason to see this film is the addition of the musical numbers -- catchy and clever songs, written in the style of classic 1950s Broadway musicals.
The Good German suggests that they can still make 'em like they used to, but also reminds us that there's more to a good movie than good looks.
Make no mistake, this movie is trash, but it's meant to be, and I'd be lying if I said it wasn't also a lot of fun.
In spite of its small shortcomings, Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest deserves praise for being an old-fashioned popcorn movie that knows how to entertain.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There are great moments, though it's ultimately a lightweight film and certainly not an Oscar contender.
Most fans are bound to be disappointed to some degree, and non-aficionados of musical theater will find it tedious and silly. Do yourself a favor and see this on stage
It's almost predictable in the way it delivers the cinematic goods, yet there's no denying that it is a compelling and entertaining look at a larger-than-life individual.
Hollywoodland is well made and boasts some strong performances. It just never reaches its full potential, but that's somehow appropriate in light of this sad story.
This isn't a bad story, but it's a bit hokey, and not nearly as imaginative as Pixar's previous triumphs.
About what you'd expect from a low budget, B-movie destined to reside among the direct-to-video releases at Blockbuster and the Saturday night features on the Sci-Fi Channel.
It's unusual to see a movie start off so strongly, only to collapse so badly by the finale. It begins like L.A. Confidential, but ends like a bad direct-to-video release.
A fine alternative to the louder and more brainless summer movies competing with it -- an excellent drama that relies on heart and action instead of schmaltz and melodrama.
A charming and dramatic tearjerker that's sweet without resorting to syrup.
Click has its heart in the right place but its head in the toilet, and thus works against itself despite some great moments.
During a fight, a character declared "Enough! It ends now." And I thought It's about time! Now there's a sure sign of an action movie falling short of its potential.
The climax is a disappointment, lacking the quick visual thrills earlier in the movie and failing to answer many key questions raised throughout.
Greatest Game succeeds because it has enough history and authenticity to please golf enthusiasts while maintaining enough heart and human drama to appeal to the rest.
Even if the story were true, the film's events have been fictionalized beyond belief.
This movie has more red herrings than an Agatha Christie novel combined with the aquarium downtown. The real question is, 'How did this stinker attract such a big name cast?'
A lot of fun and something different, poised to reach a broader audience with its silly and spirited tour of space -- which is vastly, hugely, mind-bogglingly big, by the way.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A delightfully fanciful movie with engaging storytelling, visual wonders, and such worthwhile themes as contrasting wisdom and perspective with age.
Kicking & Screaming succeeds because it understands its target audience, refraining from playing it too cute or crude. Though predictable, it's well executed.
Much like the classic spaghetti Westerns and kung fu flicks, Tarantino paradoxically manages to glorify and condemn the violence of his characters.
A strange, fun flick that loves its source material dearly, Kung Fu Hustle is destined to become a cult classic.
Perhaps it's time to admit that The Pink Panther series is ready for permanent retirement.
White Goodman is one of Stiller's craziest creations, a hilariously dim-witted and mean-spirited jock that doesn't realize how pathetic he really is.
A shaky narrative, clumsy storytelling, and unintentionally campy acting make this a frustrating movie-going experience that's only worth half the stars of its title.
Not all comic-book films have to be as weighty and angst-filled as a graphic novel. Fantastic Four is neither fantastic nor incredible, but it's entertaining nonetheless.
With filmmaking both epic and imaginative, 300 is the stuff that legends are made of.
Why do once great actors attach themselves to a dog of a picture like this? Surely they still have standards? Alas, their judgment seems to be fading . . .
It's hard not to compare, but Pixar's classy and imaginative films set the bar high, while movies like this aim too low.
Legion has the audacity to set itself up for sequels without giving the audience enough compelling reason to care about this first installment.
A touching story inspired by true events. A timely subject. Two high-profile actors in Brendan Fraser and Harrison Ford. Sadly, it all adds up to an extraordinary bore.
Hollywood has released a mainstream action movie about the Bible. If Eli sparks discussion about faith and the vitality of God's Word, that's cause for acclaim.
A rousing adventure for families, but it's the animation that truly makes the film fly higher than others in the genre.
The CGI extravaganza can't overcome all the other flaws: sloppy exposition, terrible dialogue, heavy-handed acting, and not a single likable character in the bunch.
Hubble 3D doesn't weigh in heavily on theories of Big Bangs, evolution, or creation. Instead, it lets the visual data speak for itself.
A nice, wholesome movie with a positive story about learning to be loved and to love others. Unfortunately, it's also too dull and treacly for most tastes.
I miss the days when big-budget movies actually delivered on memorable thrills and characters. Prince of Persia has neither, only a lazy script enhanced by computer-generated visuals.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A well-told cinematic example of a man who used his faith and God-given opportunities to change the world for good.
Remember the theme song? "I feel it coming together/People will see me and cry . . . Fame/I'm gonna live forever/Baby, remember my name." Sadly, none of that applies to this hollow, impersonal movie.
A fun spin on the spy genre with the seasoned veterans showing up the more inexperienced greenhorns. chances are you'll be seeing RED once the positive word of mouth hits.
For a movie showcasing flashy action, the pacing is pokey, weighed down by dull flashbacks and clichéd discussions about embracing the "digital frontier," blah, blah, blah.
Some good bits about the nature of heroism, but not enough to elevate Rango to the ranks of Pixar. Still, when viewed as a silly comedy-adventure, it's enjoyable.
I Am is less about Shadyac's radical lifestyle change than it is an exploration of humanity's shortcomings and wasted potential for good.
The 5th Quarter confuses sympathy for empathy. This story deserves better than this amateurish production.
A sucker punch is a cheap distraction for someone to gain the edge to knock the opponent senseless. That sums this up: What looks good initially will ultimately leave you flat.
What could have been a stiff and overwrought production turns out to be one of the more well-rounded and enjoyable superhero movies in recent memory.
Even the great Robert Duvall can't save this triple bogey of a movie.
Back in the first movie, Mr. Ollivander told a young Harry that we should expect great things from him. With the cinematic conclusion ten years later, he's been proven right.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Dolphin Tale has its heart in the right place and tells its story well enough for its core audience. Moralistic and sweet, there's plenty here for kids and parents to enjoy.
Funny, engaging, thought-provoking, meaningful, and one of the best family movies I've seen in a long time.
The Avengers will surely rank among the best superhero movies, if not summer blockbusters, of all time.
The film is merely okay, and that's disappointing. With such strong source material and the future of the franchise uncertain, this Voyage should have been better.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: More than anything, Astro Boy is simply fun to watch.
It's fun to see this aging cast together on screen, but the movie is junk. The one-liners aren't funny, the dialogue is tedious, and the action itself is prosaic and repetitive.
There are bound to be some 10-year-olds who will shout a hearty "Yo Joe!" (the G.I. Joe battle cry). The rest of us will more likely be crying, "Say it ain't so, Joe!"
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Not to say it's a major cinematic achievement, but it does entertain, and uniquely so.
Time to put this fairy tale to bed while it's still good and let Shrek save some face.
The film demonstrates the complexity of human nature and its faculties -- our sinful side is never far removed from our capacity to think and feel.
With its broad range of slapstick and satire, The Simpsons Movie is one of the most successful television-to cinema transplants I've ever seen.
Sometimes fun, sometimes powerful, but ultimately flawed. It promises action, but only delivers a little, decrying it while delighting in it.
In spite of its strengths for the first two-thirds, you're better off tracking down the original Sleuth than this one.
A generally fun movie as long as your expectations are low enough. But considering the talent of the cast and filmmakers, Fred Claus should be better (and funnier) than this.
Taking a cue from the Requiem of the title, it may be time to put these Aliens and Predators to rest once and for all.
Strikes a nice balance between comedy and drama, favoring humor and poignant conversations over weepy developments.
Talk about mixed movie messages -- I fear the more important part of the movie gets buried in the bloodshed. You could say that Rambo shoots himself in the foot.
A genuine crowd-pleaser overall, brisk and suspenseful%u2014more or less everything it promises to be.
21 should have followed Sin City's cardinal rule: What happens in Vegas stays in Vegas.
If we don't care about the characters or what they're playing for, then we've no reason to root for them.
Downey absolutely owns this role. He's pitch perfect as Stark, infusing the character with more personality and comedic one-liners than there ever were in the comics.
It juggles too many elements--sports, romance, slapstick, Capra-esque cinema--and doesn't do justice to any of them. But the film is brimming with nostalgia and charm.
Lacks the brain and heart of better comic book movies (like Iron Man and The Dark Knight). Wolverine's once sharp claws are wearing dull in this one.
It's fast and furious, but it's also noisy and dumb%u2014and inferior to the original in every way. Remember to use your turn signal when moving into the pass lane.
For the most part, The Haunting feels like what would happen if a real family faced unreal circumstances in their home, and that's no simple feat in the horror genre.
Simply terrible. An insult to gamers and action fans. Frankly, it doesn't even deserve notoriety as one of the year's worst; it deserves to be forgotten.
If you hated the show, you'll hate this even more. If you loved it, prepare to find your precious childhood memories drenched (literally) in dinosaur pee.
Kids will enjoy it, fans will tolerate it, geeks will feel obligated to love it, and cynics will note that at least Jar Jar doesn't make an appearance.
Mamma Mia! leaves me sending out an S.O.S., with much of the blame falling to the filmmakers. It's more akin to a music video than a musical, and a sloppy one at that.
The finale's slugfest plays out like the WWF gone CGI -- characters bash each other, things go boom, and (how typical) a lot of it is too quickly paced to follow.
A flashy mess that proves some things are better left to nostalgia than adaptation.
As far as De Niro-Pacino interaction, I'll take five minutes of Heat to a hundred minutes of Righteous Kill any day.
Greer's character ultimately gives the audience too little to root for.
This particular weirdness tumbles into juvenile relationship riffs and goofy setpieces, leaving any real grasp of ideas out of reach, as if it is jetting away on a fart-driven corpse.

Their work together is the vibrant source of the film's appeal, and "Tallulah" is at its best when the plot recedes and we get to see Page and Janney's characters testing their tolerance and eventual affection for one another.

Captain Fantastic" uses bleak but gentle comedy to pinpoint the variety of ways we wrestle with grief, but the film undermines Mortensen's performance and its own thematic ambitions by presenting the character as an idealized fantasy figure.

For the most part, however, the movie strikes its own great tone, mixing the anxious comedy of realistically awkward romantic exchanges with Rebel Wilson's more over-the-top but effectively comic antics.

"Eddie the Eagle" is as appealing and fluffy as a new pile of dry snow. The factual changes may bother the real Eddie, but this movie keeps its eye strictly on the image of achieving a thing no one expects you to achieve.
In script and performance, the film is an articulate howl of anguish and rage given depth by a discerning comprehension of the ways various communities can rely on faith for very different means.
"The Intervention" may not offer many new experiences, but its combination of tart and sweet is satisfying.

Even with its most off-putting moments, when "The Greasy Strangler" is as disgusting, deviant, and defiant as its title character, there's a real pleasure in having a new event movie for the truly weird at heart.
"Belgica" may well seem bewitching, at least for a spell, but even then the glitter will fade well before the end.
Kevin Smith's "Yoga Hosers" is a flabby, goofy, comically inert cartoon that pits two teen clerks against Canadian Nazis and little creatures made of sausage.
The terminally listless filmmaking often makes the cast look bad, and it rewards the audience's time investment with mere shreds of disposable, skimpy escapism.
In "The Good Dinosaur," Pixar appears to be reaching towards a new evolutionary movement while also keeping ties to the history of animation, and that's a true pleasure.
This "Point Break" doesn't ever connect with anything, even its own desire to celebrate the extreme.
In the end there's nothing surprising in "Sisters," except for the fact that it isn't anything more than a party movie.
"Don Verdean" could be more sharp, more focused, and it's easy to be disappointed by the film's low ambitions.

When 'The Force Awakens' is really cruising, it's a terrific piece of pulp adventure cinema, packed with memorable characters, vicious lightsaber battles, some very smart visual concepts, but its narrative shortcomings can be quite frustrating.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Iñárritu captured The Revenant in the wilds of Canada, Argentina, and the United States, using a blend of raw footage and clever computer-generated effects to create a story of survival and adventure that would curdle Jack London's blood.
Always energetic like the wild whoop of a bachelor party, the lights burn brightest when 'The Night Before' indulges in big goofs and kooky tangents.
Even dialogue scenes are paced like high-octane setpieces. There's very little downtime in this tale.
This grandiose film is visually and emotionally ripe, to the point that juices nearly sweat off the screen.
Permutations of misery and uncertainty boil under the stone surface of The Man From London, making it a too-clear mirror of dark, hidden corners.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Though Selick's process of painstakingly moving and replacing models should be antithetical to any depiction of wonder and uncertainty, an alchemical process brings the creations to life.
Fey's work is strong, yet it's difficult to squash the impression that this could be a more powerful movie, and an even more significant showcase for Tina Fey.
Bay may see the film as a cry of truth; muffled by his own predilections it's only a whisper.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: I wondered at times whether Malick and Lubezki are as seduced by the glitz and flesh of Los Angeles in very much the same way the film accuses Bale's character of falling for superficial distractions.

There's no point where Hunt for the Wilderpeople does anything that you've never seen before, but it would be crazy to hold that against a film made with such an effortlessly cultivated tone and an accommodating ear for comedy.
The intensity of his destructive tendencies increases, but empathetic ties to Davis are elusive, despite effective and committed work from Gyllenhaal and the rest of the cast.
A goofy caper almost brisk enough to escape its shortcomings.

Precisely which bits [from the source material] were warped out of shape as the film journeyed to become a Cloverfield pseudo-sequel is difficult to discern, but the end result is a failed experiment.
"Mandy" is not for everyone, but for a willing and engaged audience this is a rare artifact, a warped "hearts of darkness" journey into loss and out the other side.

Lords of Chaos puts the tale on a big stage, transforming the early days of "true Norwegian black metal" into an energetically entertaining account of partnership, identity, and betrayal even as it includes all the (very literally) gory details.

While [Sevigny] is commanding and a dedicated set of tough, engaged performances from the ensemble add life to the odd legend, awkward structural choices bleed away the film's emotional punch long before the credits roll.
This film about a sexually and socially dysfunctional guy meeting a woman far more extreme than he is foregoes incisive writing in favor of entertaining but superficial psycho-sexual twists.

The Lure's glitter does not distract from the fact that this is a technically confident and often quite accomplished piece of filmmaking, with a rare ability to dance intuitively between linear plotting and phantasmagoric fantasy.

This sequel carries forward only two ideas: that gimmick-y "assassinations that look like accidents" are a valid substitute for story, and that Jason Statham can carry an action movie even when it is propped up on such wobbly legs.
Ragussis maintains scene-to-scene tension thanks to Radcliffe's work, yet his characterization of the different extremist groups sometimes slips into the cartoonish.
This rare dramatic performance from Craig Robinson stokes a desire to see the actor given chances like this more often.
Curran guides the cast to commendable performances across the board, with Oyelowo and Wiest delivering controlled, nuanced work to fill in the script's generous negative space.
Elliot is a triumph, a new ideal for fantasy creatures.

There's no falling back on elaborate shots or effects. Any audience knows the road-trip movie and coming-of-age conceits well, and the director makes no attempt to reshape the structure. He trusts the actors and material to do the work.
The film minimizes its own best ideas in a way that undermines its attempt to decontextualize the character.
Unremarkable in scope and VFX by today's standards, even this movie barely seems to care about that brand of spectacle as it wipes cities off the map.
This is a film clever enough to scare us but not smart enough to accomplish anything more.
Warcraft provides thunderous spectacle, but when performing the alchemy of transforming genre archetypes into characters with soul, the magic fizzles out.
There's little else quite like this fast-paced, deeply funny mystery - except Shane Black's other films
Never as savage as the first-act anarchy suggests, 'Money Monster's best ideas are subsumed by familiar thriller concepts.
The turgid world-endangering plot points to yet another sequel, offering little reason to believe any of the loud action truly matters.
If only the story had the same persuasive command as its impeccable and strikingly realistic scenery.
Snyder's movie presents extremist versions of familiar characters in a tonal mishmash that indulges in more thunderous conflict than it can wrestle into coherence.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Russos deftly craft compelling blockbuster entertainment out of moral and emotional conflicts.

This episode cuts right to the core of the series's original appeal, giving the terrific cast a chance to play against one another in a straightforward story. It's not exactly bold, but "Beyond" does satisfy.
It succeeds in making the audience experience that same level of mystery and confusion that those on screen are experiencing.
A powerful digestive system can only get you so far.
Although Jackson is doubtless reserving the darkest hours for The Return of the King, we long for a greater sense of urgency in the here and now of The Two Towers.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Dawn richly rewards one's affections for the original series while delivering a tense thrill-fest. And yes, the apes as rendered by those guys down the road at Weta Digital are amazing.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This becomes a film feels like a cover version of a cover version. One that neither sends up old spy cinema nor adds much to it with its trans-Euro express of a plot.
It's a case of good start, flat middle and a curiously bad nothing-at-stake finish.
As good as this franchise gets.

Civil War feels like just another overstuffed Marvel movie working itself through a brand strategy checklist. Plenty will he happy with that. And yes, it's rather more fun than the last time a couple of superheroes went at it on the big screen.
Combined with action that shifts the usual Marvel macro battle to micro dazzle, a solid cast and a high-tech heist of a plot, Ant-Man delivers a good thing in a small package.
Together, the two timelines of Love and Mercy work in deft harmony, resulting in one of the most fascinating musical biopics in years.
This new one is easily the best sequel of the bunch. It's frequently exciting, happily, forgivably ludicrous if a little too pumped-up for its own good and less than memorable.
Aloha is Hollywood's biggest Hawaiian wreck since Michael Bay sunk those ships in Pearl Harbour.

While it's a very good video presskit for the exhibition, it makes for a peculiar sort of rockumentary. The exhibition is already one time removed from its ever-elusive subject. The film kind of telescopes that feeling.

Yes, Alex Gibney's 2013 documentary The Armstrong Lie certainly caught him in the act. But The Program offers its own exciting high-cadence take on the story. Better, it finds the chemically-enhanced pulse to Armstrong's big, beating, cheating heart.
Sure, this being Philly there's fair dollop of cheese with that steak. But Creed still packs a surprising punch.
For a movie about the Four Seasons, this sure lacks spring.
A deep dark survival thriller and a film that serves revenge as a very cold dish indeed.
Gravity becomes a character study driven by a riveting central performance and a radical thrill ride delivered with near real-time urgency which thrusts you through its implausibilities.
It is better, especially in its first half, than that previous trilogy finale.

It's a riveting, thrilling film that gets away with an ending that's perhaps just a little too keen to cleanly resolve the jagged drama. But if you ever thought Glee or Fame would be better rendered as a one-on-one psycho-thriller, here's your film.
It's in te reo but The Dead Lands never feels like it's trying too hard to say anything important. All the same, it may well become a very important film.
Yes war is hell (again), but Fury manages to its own special kind of hell. One hell of a tank movie it is too.
Despite the film doing some clunky biopic things, Otto gives this more than enough reason enough to fly down to Rio.
Washington's had much worse pulp outings than this and here he's done a bang-up job.
Definitely worth getting out of the house to see.
Guardians still feels fresh and funny and non-formulaic. They might have been comic-book margin-dwellers, but here they prove they're a headline act.
A great, deeply affecting movie.
It's movie with a fairly random sense of tone, mostly reflected by Clooney's character who is going from scared to defiant to co-operative and back again within a couple of scenes.
It ends with a bit of tailwind and will leave cycling fans with the sort of warm glow otherwise achieved only by doing a spin-class while watching the peloton climb L'Alpe d'Huez.
Gyllenhaal is terrific. It's just a pity that for all of his gym work, he's in a movie that's testing positive for melodramatic steroids.
Somehow, between its story and character contrivances and its deathless songs, Ricki and the Flash feels like a rehearsal.

The remarkable performance of young Julian Dennison as Ricky Baker, the city juvenile delinquent fostered out in the backblocks, gives Wilderpeople most of its many laughs. But he's not just there doing cute stuff and being precocious.
Not as bad as advance word - the words being "Adam Sandler movie" - would suggest. Still ...
Mark my words, there is something very funny going on here.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A comedy that manages a seemingly impossible combo: it's daring and feelgood.
It's one that makes you dread every sound of gunshot, every movement in the dark, every death. Even the final and fourteenth.
There's something about Baron Cohen's fervent and frankly Oscar-worthy performance that makes you wonder if somewhere up there, Peter Sellers is enjoying a good chuckle at his heir apparent.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Owen's compelling performance combined with Cuaron's inspired sense of doom makes Children of Men thought-provoking at a time when science fact is doing the job that science fiction once did at the movies.
Graphic novel nerds will find much to love. But too much of Renaissance is stylishly stupefying.
It's clear that FFN might be yet another hot issue drama. But it's sure hasn't been cooked all the way through.
Abandon ship. And abandon all hope of a good time, all ye who enter here.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: WOO, and indeed, hoo. The Simpsons Movie is diddily-dum-doodily.
An action movie made out of doll parts shouldn't be this much fun.

Creating the Big Lebowski of Antarctic waterfowl is just one of many inspired touches to this warmly funny romp. It more than makes up for the fact that Surf's Up missed the crest of the wave in penguin flicks.
Kenny is hilarious - toilet humour and all - and surprisingly touching. Just remember to wash your hands afterwards.

A riveting thriller led by the compelling performances of flinty Emily Blunt... a never-better Benicio del Toro as Alejandro, a enigmatically shady character who is part of a covert operation headed by Josh Brolin into which Blunt is seconded.

A prediction: The market demand for mind-altering substances is about to take a dive. For, once Inception takes hold at the cinema -- and it surely will -- this movie will have its attendees happily dazed for days, possibly weeks, afterwards.

Yes Affleck's good, Cavill fills out his suit prettily enough and when the two are going chin-to-chin, dimple-to-dimple, it makes for a mighty clash of the titans. It's just the movie they get to do that in is more batty than super.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This American film, clearly aimed at the international Bible belt, starts off as as swords and sandals detective story, with Jesus the missing person, before defaulting to a hollow gospel drama.
That frenetic fun factor helps keeps this trotting along, lessening the deadening effect of some of the characters' over-stretched personal crises.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This seems like a film that doesn't really want to be a musical.
Big Hero 6 is still a boy's own wonder. Baymax is the best movie robot in years.
Until the new Bondflick, Spectre, arrives, Vaughn's madly irreverent spin will do nicely.
This Avengers is darker, louder, stranger and soapier than the first one.
It's directed by Pierre Morel, who started the geri-action genre with Liam Neeson in Taken. This one's both more complex and stupider and barely exciting, even when it's hailing bullets.
[Furiosa is] the human touch in this inhumane world and the madly beating heart of this technical wonder of a movie.
As good as Smith's performance is, this feels like a fumble.
For a little too much of Spectre, this does feel like the same old drill. It's certainly entertaining for being just that. But a lowering of the bar after Skyfall.
The interplanetary tech geek gardening thriller of the year.
You get the sense that the real Kyle was a much more interesting figure than the one portrayed here.
The funniest thing about One Million Ways ...? How come McFarlane was much more convincing as Ted than he is here as a real person.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Adams' performance as Dr Louise Banks is terrific. She's the affecting emotional core of this. Especially once she starts her own close encounters with the inhabitants of the ship hovering above rural Montana.

movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: What started out as retro conspiracy comedy abruptly becomes paranoid thriller. It works better earlier on, as a mockumentary high on its own supply of faked lunar-landing lunacy.
Like Newt's battered suitcase it's frequently unhinged. And it's that strangeness is what makes this proto-Potter enchanting and a promising first chapter.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's a bland movie that becomes less great American business saga, more mildly engaging, mildly uncomplimentary Kroc biopic.
[It's] a blood-soaked, macabre and initially fascinating film. One where style made sure substance never got the invite to attend, then takes over the whole mad -- and maddeningly slow -- shebang.
Allied's strong sense of déjà vu sure makes it look nice. But it sure doesn't help make it a great film.

Say this about the Underworld movies: Like the vampires they are populated with, they sure do stick around. This dull heap of action-fantasy mediocrity, one which wants to be Game of Fangs, is the fifth.
It also works as its own stand-alone film. One which, despite some lumpy pacing in its first half, turns out to be possibly the best Star Wars war film of the bunch.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's got a heart, particularly in the scenes between the boys and their respective single parents, and it's got an amusingly recognisable portrayal of adolescent male friendship and the entertaining, embarrassing stupidity that can result from it.
A clever, perfect film.
A Man Called Ove is both dourly funny and affecting. A bad-mood feel-good movie.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Apart from those occasional dull patches, it is enjoyable.
The Catch can't quite hook one's attention.
Remarkably tone deaf and quite awful.

movie_review_blurb: The main characters and the performances behind them are nicely pitched.

One of the smarter and more entertaining Marvel movies of the era.
On the whole, Noah is a mad captivating trip. And yes, it's the best movie about boatbuilding and livestock export you are likely to see for a very long time.

What resonates is the movie's love story, one which is essentially about a very old, very married couple.

It's enjoyably silly fun until a third act energy slump.
Even its abundant action scenes can't save it from feeling like a greatest hits compilation of returning Bourne director Paul Greengrass' previous Supremacy and Ultimatum.

A bittersweet charmer.
That Huston is no Heston makes this a movie with an empty centre where a heroic figure should be.
Stimulating if not fascinating.

movie_review_blurb: It just might be the first plane-crash movie that suggests itself as suitable in-flight entertainment too.

As an action movie, Quantum of Solace is solid, albeit nothing memorable. But this is James Bond.
Helped greatly by excellent performances from both of the film's leads, as well as the rounded supporting cast.
Continues to shine bright as one of the most magical and delightful films in the Disney animated library.
Although some of the characters are obnoxious beyond belief, the show as a whole is just as smurfy now as it was 25 years ago.
Grounded in a gritty reality - and shot as such - it's still an action classic today that offers adrenaline-fueled pacing without insulting one's intelligence.
Finally, a solid film in which the Amazon's story can be told to current audiences.
