movie_review_blurb: A film that has little plot until the last act, yet Carrey rises above it to bring it to an acceptable level.
A movie that looks and sounds a whole lot bigger than it actually is.
Far from classic but it is interesting to watch for its take on the pre-Disnified New York landscape following the company's real estate foray into the iconic downtown core.
Takes the Disney princess and puts her in the real world, creating a chick flick with a little bit of edge, a whole lot of heart and and even more chemistry between the film's two leads.
Blindness - despite its director, despite its pedigree as a respected piece of modern literature, despite its stellar cast - is a bitter disappointment.
While it does have its weak points, it's held together by its unique angle on the war as well as strong characterization for its central characters.
Like the burnouts who stick longer than their leather jackets warrant, the shtick has gotten stale.
Sellers uses simple looks and gestures to bring light to some very serious situations. At many points it's like he's in a trance, truly embodying Chance.
Took the sleaze of the teen comedy and spun it into something that's both hugely entertaining and extremely insightful.

Despite some memorable musical numbers, gorgeous sets and energy galore, there's something about Funny Face that wasn't working for me, and it wasn't just the absurd idea about Audrey Hepburn being a frumpy bore.
Two seasons in, The Tudors continues to be one of television's sexiest and sultry shows and one rooted in the history books to boot.
Mixing drama, comedy and horror, Dexter's first season presents itself an unforgettable and highly addicting look inside the mind of the world's most sympathetic psychopath.
Occasionally interesting, always beautiful and regularly tedious, the film attempts to capture a time and a feeling yet it ultimately fails to provide the depth needed to make it wholly successful.
When it comes to cinematic fashion and romance, perhaps none are more iconic than Blake Edwards' Breakfast at Tiffany's.
Pop fluff intended for kids stuck between Dora the Explorer and Gossip Girl. Consider it a bonus that it's tolerable, if not fun, for the rest of us as well.
At its simplest, it's a gorgeous film with beautiful period costumes and intricate set designs. However, something tells me that's not the level director Saul Dibb wanted to achieve greatest on.
Enjoyable, silly and a wee bit whimsical. It's also treacherously predictable at times, the two leads lack chemistry and it has the token horrible Rob Schneider cameo.
While it does have some solid moments of action, the film as a whole is laughable.
Zhang weaves a complex and interesting story but the ultimate strength of Hero is its poetic beauty.
Despite its seemingly constant action, the focus was way too light for my liking, resulting in a film that's often more corny than it is enthralling.
Reminds us that no matter where you are, this third rock from the sun of ours is a gorgeous thing.
Has many moments rooted in movie magic, but there's also a whole lot of filler that brings the movie to a length that's more than bearable.

Collecting all 52 of the short films produced by MGM between 1938 and 1944 for the first time, The Our Gang Collection presents a time capsule of sorts of the franchise during a decline in its popularity.
Although it's hampered by rushed pacing and some plot contrivances, Bad Ronald isn't actually that bad.
Sticks to the familiar but he does it in such a way that it's still extremely creepy, a little bit campy and, at times, quite a lot of fun.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid of the Dark (1973)

movie_review_blurb: Although the drama goes a little too Shakespearian at times to the point of predictability, the show's an intelligent and human take on a subject that is normally either idolized or cartoonized.
Adventureland finds much of its comedy in its often brutal honesty.

Several anti-war films have come along in the past couple of years calling out the war in Iraq. They've covered various conspiracies, big personalities and the front lines. But, perhaps, none have been as human as Neil Abramson's American Son.

While not at its best, it's still a smarter and funnier show than nearly everything else you're bound to find on TV, DVD or some basement box holding some slowly rotting bootleg VHS tapes of a show that lasted six episodes back in 1986.
Well acted, a multi-leveled story and a pure honesty make Sling Blade one of my favourite films of the 1990s.
Hawks and his cast and crew make El Dorado seem so easy. It's like a refined blockbuster that's confident in hitting its ability to hit the right notes.
A funny, often hilarious, film that proves that a story doesn't need to be completely new just as long as there's a spin on it to make it different.
Boring, annoying and not funny, Pete's Dragon is one of the dullest films from Disney that I've ever seen.
There's nothing that stands out in any way from the script to the directing to the acting.
Boring and unoriginal, this new version might have some fancy visuals and a loud soundtrack but they're just a smokescreen for how boring and lifeless the film is.
More interested in the villain than the hero, First Flight is a bland look at one of the sides of the DC universe that's normally much more interesting.
Generic at its core, the idea behind the movie is valiant enough but happy themes aren't enough to carry an otherwise boring film.
Charm can go a long way in making a film. Or, in the case of Confessions of a Shopaholic, the charm of Isla Fisher makes the film bearable.
At their best, Tom and Jerry embraces chaos and animated anarchy.
A story about people rather than just one a team going for the win. In doing so, O'Connor makes Miracle one of the more thoughtful and enjoyable films revolving around sports.
A film that is at times laughable yet at the same time, over 15 years after its release, its premise is still up for debate and discussion.
An exceptionally well-written, well-acted and well-directed thriller that extends beyond the boundaries mainstream films typically set.
With time as a buffer, it's now easier to see The Machinist for what it is: a labyrinthine leap down the rabbit hole into a nightmarish wonderland.
It's got the mystery aspect down beautifully, but because I wasn't given a chance to get behind the characters and get to know them, I had a hard time getting into the film itself.
The film is sweet and innocent, just as one might expect. While not horrible, I can't heap praise on it either.
Violent and bloody, carefully choreographed and filled with dry humor, Takeshi Kitano's modern take on the classic Japanese character is a unique vision that's told with confidence.
The issues it tackles are just as relevant now (if not more so) than they were when the film was first released theatrically back in 1997.

American Teen presents itself as getting inside the lives of America's current youth culture. But the very idea of individuality is lost because it doesn't go deep enough into the lives of its subjects to fully convey the idea.

I can't help but think that 10,000 BC started out as an idea that sounded like, "Wouldn't it be cool if we had wooly mammoths and saber toothed tigers and people all in the same movie?" and went from there.
Based on the series of five serial children's novels, The Spiderwick Chronicles is a hollow spectacle that's good for the action and effects but light on everything else.
It's like doing a puzzle a second time. It's familiar, it's redundant and it's rarely exciting.

Maintains a very high standard of comedy and imagination but it also shows signs of developing. It keeps the show's spirit and also shows viewers that there's more waiting beyond the lights and curtains they're used to.

Drawn Together is sort of a nostalgia trip for the Captain Crunch generation. But just because you're rude, crude and reference The A-Team on multiple occasions it doesn't mean you're classic yourself.
Of the three Young Indiana Jones DVD sets, this is the first one that begins to capture the same sense of adventure found in the films.
Richard LaGravense's P.S. I Love You has plenty of sappy love-letter moments, but it's also a very touching and real-feeling look at the grieving process.
A few cute gags aside, this is an exercise in stupidity aimed at those who find 15 different names for a bong to be funny.
Originally made for IMAX screens, George Butler's Roving Mars is a visual marvel %u2013 even if it boils down to a piece of corporate propaganda.
The visuals, the pacing, an all-time great performance and a timely theme add up to make There Will Be Blood one of the most memorable films I have seen.
Another bizarre and beautiful excursion courtesy of one of Hollywood's most creative minds.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Shrinking him and his cronies down into Fisher Price Little People, Bush rules the school much like he does America %u2013 with a lot of help from his friends and direction from his papa.
Feels so forced and determined to convey a certain emotion that its authenticity is lost. And when there's no sense of authenticity, there's no emotional attachment.

Thank goodness that experiment in appeasing the commercial suit types is over and the quirky brothers are back to form with No Country for Old Men, a dark and violent exploration of nature's hunt and the relevance of time.
Because it touches on the universal themes of loss and love so honestly, it is a film that feels authentic even in its many contrivances.
Into the Wild is a film to meditate on. It's long, it's not particularly fast-moving but it struck me in a carnal fashion.
"Cute and cuddly" pretty much sums up this canine caper - once you get past the idea of a lady looking to make a coat out of dalmatian puppies.
Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones may have updated The Fugitive for modern times as a thrilling film with a bigger train wreck, but there's nothing like the original.
Robert Zemeckis' take on Beowulf is a marvel visually but eye-popping effects are still no challenge for good old-fashioned human emotion.
Buoyed by likeable characters and the ever-dependable super teacher construct, We Shall Overcome builds into a better-than-solid underdog story.
With gentle plotting the intensity builds and builds until it all boils over.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A depressing thinker of a film that also offers a little nostalgia to boot.
The Aristocats is largely an up-scale cat version of 101 Dalmatians minus the deliciously dastardly villain.

The reason why Gone Baby Gone works so well is the attention to which Boston is portrayed. The urban neighbourhood is like another character in an already strong cast, one that has needs and desires just like everyone else.
Even though it looked great and was moderately engaging, something was also always missing.
Offering an iconic lead, a bag filled with various villains and a classic Western structure, Gunsmoke manages to entertain more than 50 years after it first aired.
Bee Movie is a solid mix of comforting gags, clever language and a meandering plot that doesn't seem to have enough gas to stretch out into a full feature.
A delightful comedy with an edge of romance that is taken down a notch from its utterly drippy ending.

Part The Graduate, part Fitzcarraldo, The Art of Travel is a tribute to living on the road less traveled. Filmed entirely on location, it offers a more rounded portrayal of culture outside of the standard Hollywood clichés
Has enough heart and insight into the complexities of being a teenager today that you can overlook some of its other shortcomings - primarily in the tired act of the titular character.
While the film is over the top at times, Coach Carter has a big heart that doesn't shy away from challenging the American education system.
When it's on the racetrack, it's thrills abound as the big sound and fast-moving cars make for sensory overload. However, when the action fades and it's time to give the characters some meat.
Paul W.S. Anderson's outer space horror Event Horizon is an example of a potentially great and complex idea given a simplistic and ultimately ridiculous execution.

Attempting to tap into the public's collective fears and suspicions comes D.J. Caruso's preposterous Eagle Eye, an action film with plenty of thrills but I have no idea what alternate reality it's set in.
Andrew Adamson shows a more confident and defined vision that works on several levels, however it's unable to overcome a nagging feel of disconnect.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Made at the time as a plead for international peace, its message should still ring true today where the world picture is more complex and, in many ways, more splintered and dangerous.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951)

movie_review_blurb: Horton started as a book, less that 40 pages long. To make it a feature seems just a little bit wrong. The magic of Seuss isn't quite there. It's got the look but it's missing some flair.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Leave it to Stephen Colbert to go post modern on the Christmas special and come up with a cheeky variety-format program of his own to take the modern mantle in the holiday television canon.
movie_title: A Colbert Christmas: The Greatest Gift of All (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The action movie has been spoofing itself for years. Half of the time it's no even intentional. Ben Stiller's hilarious and surprisingly intelligent Tropic Thunder takes the genre spoof to a new extreme.
Sure, it takes a familiar road, but there's certainly enough bubbling under the surface to keep the heart of the film relevant and appealing more than a half-century later.
Tears away at the curtain that keeps reality away from fiction.
Mixes the romantic comedy formula of an unlikely couple slowly falling in love with some classic slapstick to create a movie that's tough not to be delighted by.
Even in pointing out the falseness of talking down to people for the sake of coming across as intelligent, Smart People does just that.
The fact is, while Kidulthood tries to be raw and gritty, it's really just a mish-mash of events that's missing characters that you genuinely care for or even begin to understand.
Although something of a confusing and befuddling mess, Miike's foray into the Western genre, Sukiyaki Western Django is another showcase for his playful and often gory style.
Simplicity and complexity harmonize together in cinematic zen in the instant-classic WALL-E, a film that uses technical prowess to tell a straight-forward yet far-reaching story.
Transsiberian is a deeply engrossing film from the get go. It sucked me in with a simple, yet often overlooked, idea - interesting characters.

With its sophisticated yet accessible blend of comedy and the macabre, I knew Beetlejuice was likely to be one of those films I would never tire of. But a classic? It's been 20 years. I'm willing to throw that blue ribbon on it.

Although it carries a certain level of slickness to it, Kingdom of the Crystal Skull shows that although the times have changed - both in the film and for the viewing audience - Indiana Jones hasn't. And that's a problem.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While it's better than your average film in a lot of respects, it simply cannot hold up to the legacy of its predecessors.

While I'm sure profits were a big part of the conversation the Paramount suits had when deciding to green-light The Godfather Part II, but Coppola didn't go out and bastardize the franchise. Far from it.
Coppola offers a rich and layered look at family and does so with an incredible cast and a meticulous amount of detail.

The Disney tween machine continues to plug along mixing sugar-pop ballads with the simple structure of summer camp in Camp Rock. The familiarity makes for something comfortable, nothing spectacular, but mindlessly enjoyable.
Terrifying Times is a timely look at the Western-dominated world from the point of view of someone who's firmly plugged into the inner workings of the American political machine.

Although there are many familiar elements, the overall look and feel of Transformers Animated is very different from the original show. It's not all a bad thing just as long as I remember that I'm no longer the target audience.
More than a concert film, Scorsese's Shine a Light not only throws yet another spotlight on the rockers but also carves out a story to pay tribute to the "Satisfaction" musicians.
Offers some of the strangest and worst the movies have to offer and makes it, at the very least, watchable if not entertaining.

Magic swords, beautiful enchantresses, approaching darkness, sweeping landscapes, white bearded wizards, it`s all been done before. Yet the first season of The Legend of the Seeker makes a lot of it feel fresh.
The complex show is a unique mix of cop show, drama, comedy and science fiction that insists the viewer look beyond the obvious. Or does it?
Featuring beautiful nature animation and possessing a passable plot, if nothing else, Tinker Bell and the Lost Treasure opens up a world beyond the Never Land everyone seemingly knows.
movie_title: Tinker Bell and the Lost Treasure (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Despite a couple of uneven parts that may try the patience of some, the whole of Fantasia is a marvel.
Plays an honorable game, tackling the touchy subject of ageism on the baseball field. But it's ultimately a hollow attempt, one that thinks that just by touching on a subject that it makes up a plot.
[Sizemore's] performance can best be summed up as Al Pacino by way of Moe from The Three Stooges.
A cold biopic that doesn't hold up now that its subject matter has left the spotlight.

Although it might be a love story to baseball and the competitive spirit to win, it's also redundant as a film when like footage and story lines can be found on any station that airs even a little bit of baseball.
An instant classic of unabashed nostalgia.
A complex crime drama that limits its action, opting to save it for the times that bring the greatest impact.
Short and sweet, it's also intelligent and a welcome departure from the typical material found in the genre's bigger stars.
movie_title: Zach Galifianakis: Live at the Purple Onion (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Jacques Perrin's spectacular documentary takes observation a step further as he literally seems to take flight with flocks of birds as they make their annual migration.
[Bell] carries a classic presence and charm that is tough not to like. Yet, at the same time, she does so with a little spunk and sass.
Hangs a neon sign around the key set-up points and lights off fireworks around them so that it's easy to see exactly what the big reveals will be.
While Solondz tries and tries hard, Storytelling fails to provide much more insight than the inside column of a torn book jacket.
Although magnificent and filled with imagination, Fantasia 2000 doesn't hold up as being particularly ground-breaking or innovative.
A rebel film both in its subject matter and its unorthodox distribution.
Although it's been a long time since 1918, there are still lessons to be learned from Shoulder Arms.
The overall voyage on The Salton Sea is an uneasy one hampered by a confusing story that admits out loud it doesn't know where it's going.
It's all about the set-up and not the actual payoff.
A 90-minute collection of clever and frank dialogue about sex and relationships.
A very confident picture that is carefully constructed and immensely intriguing.
Sticks to relying on nostalgia rather than making something truly memorable itself.
movie_title: Un ete sans point ni coup sur (A No-Hit No-Run Summer) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An intimate, albeit uneventful, story filled with flashy graphics but not a lot of substance.
A fascinating behind-the-scenes documentary that charts not only a story of tremendous success but sibling rivalry as well.
movie_title: The Boys: The Sherman Brothers' Story (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The best film about bullying ever made.
movie_title: The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance (1962)

movie_review_blurb: A cheeky look at the disdain aimed at the Ontario capital from the rest of Canada.
Just enough story to be interesting and with lots of personality to stand out.
movie_title: The Legend of Drunken Master (Jui kuen II) (Drunken Fist II) (1994)

movie_review_blurb: At times serious, others farcical, it's a film that ignores expectations and creates an experience that's like a helium balloon. It slowly lets itself out before finally settling.
movie_title: The Joy of Singing (Le Plaisir de Chanter) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Although sometimes a little too cartoonish, the cast is an enjoyable lot with plenty going on to drive the film forward.
A medley of familiar Christmas classics...with a distinct Muppet spin.
movie_title: It's a Very Merry Muppet Christmas Movie (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Instead it feels more like a publicity stunt meant to up the stock of Mantle, Maris and the polarizing New York Yankees.
More like an infomercial in disguise for the soundtrack.
The Perfect Game proves that you don't always have to reach for lofty heights to work. It's certainly not a classic. It's a simple pleasure for those times when that's all you need.
Touching Home is stronger when it focuses on the small-town life than when it steps on the ball diamond. The decent cast elevates it to a tolerable level.
Chasing 3000 is a nostalgia-fueled bore that uses baseball history as a backdrop for a formulaic road trip movie.
Filled with heavy dialogue, Game 6 is a film that feels more appropriate for the stage. That said, it takes on challenging themes and deep thoughts.
A lively celebration of baseball as America's pastime set during an era where the game was at its peak.
To a batter, a great curveball is so obvious and so frustrating at the same time. Robert Lorenz's Trouble with the Curve is much the same.
Roskam shows the most confidence when things are unsettling and different from the genre underworld in which the plot resides.
Although somewhat soft in tackling some of the more controversial aspects, it is still a fascinating look at the sport outside of the bright stadium lights and manicured lawns of the big leagues.
movie_title: Rumbo a Las Grandes Ligas (Road to the Big Leagues) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Filled with pain disguised as comedy, it presents a real-life Peter Pan complex where letting go of one's youth is complicated and painful.
What once caused a storm of controversy is now pretty tame, mundane even.
Keeps the economic talk in check and brings the human drama to the forefront.
While The Rocketeer never crashes, it's a bumpy ride of cartoonish characters, a flimsy plot and an overall sense of letdown.
A fascinating look at early baseball films and an un-perfected spin on something that has since gone on to be repeated countless times since.
By offering an insightful look at some of the key players that made it happen, Shatner is able to break down some of the barriers that scare some people off from the Star Trek franchise.
They're still fun at times and remain iconic but there's something about these shorts where the cute factor wears thin and the stories seem to be calling it in.
The latest in a growing number of weepy films based on Nicholas Sparks novels that don't come anywhere close to The Notebook.
Falls into the path of giving a message more than it does letting things emerge organically.
The drinking, partying and sex come across more as a means to shock than actually make some sort of statement.
Edwards proves that he was a more diverse filmmaker than perhaps he was given credit for.
One of the worst family films I've seen since another animated adaptation: Garfield. Talking bears aside, the film lacks logic, energy and, most of all, fun.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
It wanders through the desert, looking for an exciting hook but never finding one.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: To does a fantastic job of providing a good sense of style and structure to the numerous action scenes, but they're not over the top or cartoonish.
Continues to steer the same course as its predecessor sequels, focusing on convoluted storylines that zap all the fun and energy that made the first film so great.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A solid film of somewhat dated Cold War-era warnings of global conquest and strife filled with moments that are both dramatic and laughable at the same time.
A playful film that calls on its audience to believe in the empowering virtues of imagination and freedom.
Combining honest commentary with archival footage, Waking Sleeping Beauty offers a refreshing look at a side large companies often steer clear of.
Despite showing some potential as commentary on ageism, the light-hearted comedy often flounders in the formulaic and a premise that is more complicated than it needed to be.
Beautiful and thoughtful, Miyazaki once again shows he's a master of taking the magical and making it endearing.
An excellent alternative to much of the frenetic, princess-driven fare that seems to dominate the genre.
A surreal experience that is both a beautiful and somewhat frustrating.
A film with a few inspired moments - mostly towards the end - sprinkled in with a whole lot of awkward, even mean, portions. The result is a major disappointment.
Has a strong visual style but a horrible story.
With its subject matter, it could have easily delved into the depths of a TV movie of the week filled with melodramatics and distant characterizations.
movie_title: L'Empreinte de l'ange (Mark of an Angel) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Although overly long, this mini-series offers an intelligent, albeit light-hearted look at love and longing.
Takes pain and loss and gives it a slightly glossy treatment that holds the drama but doesn't quite get to the point of complete emotional puppetry.
At times serious, others farcical, it's a film that ignores expectations and creates an experience that's like a helium balloon. It slowly lets itself out before finally settling.
Collects the five surviving stories that all share the same breezy attitude and distracting production values.
A film that raises many interesting ideas but follows through on few of them.
Told from the insider's perspective of Harry Warner's granddaughter Cass Warner, comes a slightly Michael Moore-esque look at the establishment of the Warner empire in Hollywood.

Dark and edgy, it goes beyond traditional thrillers and infuses a deep sense of emotion and commentary to create a truly dynamic production. Factor in the great cast and an anything-goes attitude and you've got five hours of riveting viewing.
A classic Judge film: somewhat uneven but filled with interesting, albeit clueless, characters and funny set-ups.
Aside from the charming technical aspects, A Miser Brothers' Christmas is a fat lump of coal in the Christmas special canon.
Although there's a couple of cute spots with Snoopy, there's little else that's even remotely memorable.
movie_title: I Want a Dog for Christmas, Charlie Brown (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some great game action and an in-depth narration from Bryant himself, the documentary falls into the trap of glitz and glamor distracting from the subject matter it's intending to celebrate.
Santa Buddies is the equivalent of a flaming bag of doggie dung on your doorstep: it's impossible to explain what you did to deserve it and you want it gone and forgotten as soon as possible.
The epitome of self indulgence.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: There's no denying the raw and energetic feel Smith created with a memorable script, great characters and a genuine sense of Gen X angst.

Smith's most mature film. Yes, it's filled with crude dialogue, blunt descriptions of sex and an overkill of Star Wars references, but it uses these to dig deeper and make its subject matter more accessible.
Monsters, Inc. is a celebration of unforgettable characters and a world unlike any other.
Filled with wonderment and intrigue, it tells a timeless tale of adventure and aging that touches on almost every emotion.
An exercise in tedium and yearning for the good, old days where straight-up action films were respected by the masses.
I am curious if some of the humor I see in it now was intentional three decades ago. Regardless, how can you go wrong with a villain like a clam in an eye-patch or a disco-dancing mummy?
Takes an old story and proves the themes are timeless by applying them to a modern setting.
Feeling like a collection of Disney Princess greatest hits with a Southern flair, this latest Disney animated feature may look gorgeous but it's lacking in "magic."
Has the distinction of being one of those movies that's so bad it actually has some solid entertainment value.

It's easy to be sucked in by all the glossy, nostalgic images that flash across the screen like some sort of psychological experiment, but like most of the director's other films, most is forgettable shortly thereafter.
It pulls out all the stops in hitting all the familiarities of the genre and spins it on its head in both a fun and intelligent way.
Full Throttle would have worked if it were a promo video for a Hollywood stunt school. But you can only defy gravity so many times before you go floating off into space.
A celebratory film made by those who hold the place close to their heart.
Told from the insider's perspective of Harry Warner's granddaughter Cass Warner, comes a slightly Michael Moore-esque look at the establishment of the Warner empire in Hollywood.
The film focuses more on getting its message, no matter how noble, across rather than focusing on basic storytelling.
Writer/director Davidowski makes a valiant effort in looking further into the soul of his characters and in turn making a familiar story deeper and more believable.
Captures the author's spirit, creating a film with not only whimsical creatures but very real emotions.
Pixar have once again reminded me that there is a way to create a film that not only appeals to just about everyone, but also prove that three-quels need not suck.
Full of interesting characters and placed in a charged setting, but the preachy and obvious spin it takes is ultimately melodramatic and predictable.

It's by no means some sort of quote-whoringly "fantastic stuff," "the best baseball movie since Ken Burns took 18 hours of my life" or even "a home run." Sometimes a solid single is all that it takes.
There is something delightful in the absurdity and chaos of the movie that kept my interest even as I struggled to pinpoint exactly what it was that I was watching.
An odd film with little story, Headin' Home has a big place in sports history, offering an early look at Babe Ruth.

A monkey playing baseball, what could be cuter? In the case of Bill Couturié's Ed, you could slap Chunk from The Goonies in in some Victoria's Secret lingerie and you'd have something more attractive.
Never mind the fact that the plot regularly goes off track and into the rough, Caddyshack offers laughs a plenty.
In Daniel Kraus' dark baseball film Ball of Wax, life on the diamond is clearly no longer a sport. It's something sinister, like a virus refusing to let go of its host.
So how much more can they get out of cussing kiddies playing baseball? Apparently an additional 91 minutes - 91 painful, horrendous, baseball-bat-to-the-crotch-three-times minutes.
movie_title: The Bad News Bears Go To Japan (1978)

movie_review_blurb: A film with lots of great ideas yet none of them come to fruition.
Amidst a script that starts, stalls and plods along, Stewart is an inspiration who could probably tell 'Yo Mamma jokes to the Brady clan and Partridge family and still be their best friend.
The comedic value of kids talking like a bitter pirate with hemorrhoids and smoking [was] played out mid-way through the first film.
movie_title: The Bad News Bears in Breaking Training (1977)

movie_review_blurb: Clichés are easy and when you go the easy route in sports, the losses will add up.
Fresh perspectives offer fresh ideas, even if they don't result in a smile and a happy Frank Sinatra song about love.
Akin to a bloop single: it's not pretty but it gets the job done, even if only for a little bit.
The film remains timely for the themes of fame and success it explores with such great scope and emotion
Martin Campbell returns to the once edgy and jagged ground of his excellent BBC miniseries Edge of Darkness with a much slicker spin that sheds much of what made the first go around so good.
While not a horrible film, it certainly isn't the type of feature that would make anyone an icon or even a star.
It's rare that a movie can inspire genuine awe but Cameron has succeeded in another landmark technical achievement.
One of the finest Westerns to come along since the genre decided largely to pack up and ride into the sunset several decades ago.
Cloverfield brings chaos and terror in one of the most memorable American monster films in some time.
A poorly animated tale that offers little new to the genre or the Dungeons and Dragons franchise in which it is based.
Although it starts out somewhat bland, as the season progresses and the ideas are made more clear, Dollhouse emerges as a smart, sexy, action-packed techno-drama.
This second DVD installment of The Adventures of Young Indiana Jones still lacks a lot of the qualities that made the films in which it was based so entertaining.
Not as big as James Cameron's computer-generated bonanza, but it's nonetheless impressive.
I'm optimistic when it comes to spending a rainy Sunday with one of Michael Crichton's books, but I'd be far less excited to see another of his films.
And I thought the slow-motion flying flesh of The Passion of the Mel was sadistic. It's Herbie Goes to Monte Carlo placed alongside James Wan's grizzly Saw.
Shows America's beauty through its warts and blemishes, something that even today is often overlooked.
Covers a lot of ground - too much - in its attempts to be all-encompassing.
Doesn't completely hold up a half century after its release, but it is a nostalgic bit of innocent humour.
Explores the structure of the family in its many possible forms and makes an argument that Colin Farrell is perhaps one of the most charming blokes on the planet.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Fights bias with bias.
movie_title: Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A cheeky and intelligent look at a more disturbing side of live theatre.
Very much an Al Pacino vehicle, not that this is a bad thing.
There's a lot to be said about a family with 12 kids but this film doesn't do any of them justice.
Explores legends and entombs myths into a film that is timeless and will live on as a work of art even if the western as we once knew it disappeared alongside its heroes.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

movie_review_blurb: Marks the umpteenth comeback for Travolta. It's a modest one, but a comeback simply because it's watchable Travolta that doesn't reek of a paycheck grab.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It's not funny, it tells a surface story and nothing more, and there's no sense of effort to correct any of these deficiencies.
The first two thirds are a lot of fun and a showcase for Robert Downey Jr.'s immense talents.
Buoyed by a strong cast and carried by an interesting mix of genre sensibilities, it's a film that may not have much lasting value but is fun nonetheless.
Even when the story lingers at times, the central character is played so strongly that you can still stay with the film.
While some might call it "gritty," the film never goes below the surface.
Shows some promise in that it wants to say something, but there are plenty of forgettable moments to go along with it.
Quote not available.
In his quest to outsmart his audience and outdo his previous films Shymalan has become, dare I say it, predictable.
Touches on feminist ideals that are all but contradicted by a pair of skimpy leather pants.
Important not so much in that it is a great documentary, but it raises some of the implications of our own biased media coverage.
Like a peacock showing its bright colours. Sadly, it's all about show, not substance.
Photographs tell stories, and in this case, they tell more than shots of guys looking for photos.
Even though it flaunts its wealth, It Runs in the Family is a worthy tribute to all things Douglas.
The success of Nobody's Fool lies with its actors.
There is little balance given to the Afghan people shown here.
Much like basking in front of your own image, Spacey's Beyond the Sea is a vanity project, albeit one with some interesting layers surrounding it.
A purposely corny but thoroughly entertaining piece of melting pot cinema.
A grim exploration of [humanity's] futile attempts to repress the urge for violence.
Sure, it's simple but for a longtime Dukes of Hazzard fan, it's a funny and nostalgic dose of Southern comfort.
Brown lays the sentimentality on so much that it almost brings the whole production down. Luckily there's lots of tremendous shots and a solid story to keep it going.
While Elephant was a success stylistically, Ben Coccio's Zero Day is more haunting and hits home harder.
Quote not available.
Sometimes the simplest conflicts are the best ones...The result is a film that packs more emotion than anything I have seen in at least a couple of years.
A very well acted film with a tremendous ensemble cast. My problem stems from how Araki chose to tell the story.
There's nothing new thematically with Night Watch. However, Bekmambetov puts enough of a fingerprint on the project to make it all seem fresh again.
My eyes hurt. So much action. So many explosions. So few words.
There is a lot to become enchanted with - even if it looks as though most every character were a product of computer animation.
Clear, to the point but not entirely grabbing.
Like Nomi's work, there is some distinct style at play that reflects its subject matter.
The best scenes are the ones that show the chaos of what was happening....Unfortunately such scenes are too few.
Avoids political views and is instead a tribute to the John and Jane Smiths of the American military risking their lives for an ideal rather than a clear goal.
How many ways can you tell a fart joke? Dreamworks Animation continues to ponder the question that has puzzled humanity with Madagascar.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
After Boyle establishes Damian, his family and his quirky new community, Millions really starts to lag. The imagination gives way to simple subplots.
Denys Arcand light.
While he doesn't necessarily sympathize with Hitler and his cronies, Oliver Hirschbiegel does make the fuehrer seem almost human with Downfall.
Red Trousers pays tribute to one country's stuntmen. At the same time it's a personal tribute as Shou uses the film as a platform to showcase his own work.
movie_title: Red Trousers: The Life of the Hong Kong Stuntmen (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
More than finger pointing and a recap of events. By delving into Dallaire's psyche, it becomes an emotional and poignant journey.
movie_title: Shake Hands with the Devil: The Journey of Romeo Dallaire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Starkweather is the kind of mean-spirited film that uses violence as a way of selling itself and shocking its audience.
While the story is very original combining the techno-edge of The Matrix with Orson Welles' The Trial, it's the mood and atmosphere where it really shines.
A truly original work, and a very cheeky one at that filled with end-to-end laughter. It plays off Herzog's own legend as a behind-the-camera wild card.
War of the Worlds confronts the West's collective feelings of vulnerability but at the same time it reassures our potential for survival.
The Taylor brothers make good use of the tools they have to compliment their deep imaginations and passion for making a good flick.
Had the potential to be something better, and without much additional effort.
Despite memorable main characters, a half-decent take on an overused premise, and unforgettable scenes, the film's attitude and political stance haven't aged with grace.
Although the relationship between Oliver and Jennifer remains one of the best ever produced, [it] lacks excitement and tension that are primary ingredients for any movie.
An easy watch, except for the annoying demeanour of its lead character.
A moral fable in which the deepest analysis comes from the politics surrounding the film rather than the lifeless garbage found within the movie.
Something is missing. Actually, a lot is missing.
No matter the begging and pleading, Mercy should be taken out back and buried. Better yet, blow it up first and then bury it.
At a running time of just under two full hours, the boredom becomes as exaggerated as the wallpaper.

On the surface, Stardust looks like a cheesy little fluff fantasy. In many ways it is. Yet at the same time, it's also the most fun I've had with a film since watching the first Pirates of the Caribbean.
Because it aims to tell the entire story of basketball in just 90 minutes, 1 Love glosses over most of its material, leaving us wanting more.
Although director Ralph Bakshi's imagination is certainly present, Cool World is too full of itself to create any magic.
As a big fan of the original, I'd just as soon not acknowledge this film exists. My hunch is that stars Eric Christian Olsen and Derek Richardson feel similarly.
movie_title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Succeeds in reintroducing the Looney Tunes name, but fails to capture the imagination and sharpness that defined them originally.
Coscarelli goes beyond the traditional cult status, opting for something that is fun and deep. At least there's times where it's like that.
With a fearlessness for being honest, the situations the characters find themselves in are embarrassing and laugh-out-loud funny.
It's either an ode to the old-style noir genre or it's a barely disguised rip off, and I'm leaning toward the latter.
While it's easy and fair to praise Peter Sellers for his work under many guises, it's the cheeky and slightly subversive attitude of the script that kept my attention.
Quite embarrassing, really, especially with the overacting of Dan Aykroyd.
Like the rest of the film, Diane Lane is smart, pretty and charming in the most classical of senses.
A tame mix of jokes that haven't stood up over the years and misunderstandings that likely weren't all that funny to begin with.
movie_title: Don't Raise the Bridge, Lower the River (1968)

movie_review_blurb: It's all about energy. It's constant and, for me, addicting.
It tells a clear story with a humorous voice, sharp imagery and an eye for nuance.
Never fails to take me back to a place of welcomed innocence yet it doesn't make me wish I were back there.
A hilarious holiday film in which Ferrell continues to play the same adorable, naive persona he's adopted as his shtick.
Just because The Ref isn't your typical Christmas movie doesn't mean you should skip it. In fact, it should be just the opposite.
Like a car accident unfolding before your eyes, it's impossible to look away even if only to see how just bad it can get.
While [this] version of the Christmas spirit on trial as written by John Hughes isn't awful, it's also more disappointing than Seaton's take nearly half a century earlier.
In making it horribly bad, Jack Frost is at the very least entertaining. And is there anything else you could ask for from a B-movie about a serial-killing snowman?
Ginger Snaps is a satisfying return to mythology, cheesy gore and fear for the horror film.
Part science fiction, part romance, part nothing you've ever seen before, Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind is a fresh spin on love and all things rosy and scary.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: I wanted to be moved. Really, I did. A lot. Instead, I left cold.
As gripping as they come. It's a unique film that freely jumps genres in order to tell the best story possible.
Pelosi's willingness to open up and look into her own spot in the campaign frenzy makes this meta-documentary important the media and those who consume it.
Takes horror on a quirky self-referential journey with equals parts comedy and walloped body parts.
It's the end of the world and it looks just fine.
Made all the more fascinating by keeping a small and twisted foot in a bizarre reality befitting the glitz and glamour of show business.
Senseless sequels aren't always limited to cheesy action flicks and comic book adaptations.
Little more than a timeline doodle instead of a deep and meaningful portrait.
A call to be yourself in light of those around you and have confidence in whatever your 'skills' may be, no matter how geeky or nerdish.
Ultimately, a heartbreaking film that refuses to take the easy, happy route of life.
The fantastically cartoonish look isn't enough to compensate for the plodding story and overall disinterest I had in the characters.
Even with the normally loveable Jack Lemmon as its star and a script from Neil Simon, it's a dreary bore.
This isn't the Grade Three incarnation of Harry Potter anymore.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Had the Universal Monsters at its whim and gave us Wild, Wild West in a trenchcoat.
Has just enough substance beneath the surface throw the romantic comedy some much needed freshness.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The Delicate Art of Parking is held together because of its strong characters. They're funny, they're quirky and, most of all, they're realistic.
Super Size Me is more important for what it brings to the table outside of the film rather than the film itself.
While Porky's may have spawned hundreds, if not thousands, of imitators, it's having trouble keeping up with the barriers it broke more than two decades ago.
The costumes, the sets, the music, the choreography, the dialogue - all are beautiful and from the eye of a genuine vision.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: No Turning Back is intense at its core, looking at not just the tough choices we make but the process that goes into making them.
Misses a huge opportunity to make a scathing commentary on the isolation similar townships and villages feel.
This part of the story peels away at the heart and emotions of its central characters.
The Corporation is another strike against suits, board room meetings and the brands and chain stores we know we should hate but we use anyways.
Sets an example for future religious films. It's able to get its point and purpose across in a way that's both entertaining and doesn't alienate the broader audience.
The names of Lillian Gish, Bette Davis and Vincent Price will never be forgotten by film lovers. The Whales of August, on the other hand, surely will be.
What makes it stand out is the fact that there's some subversive politics happening beyond the fighting that is refreshing.
[Feels] like Hollywood execs are trying to get the Coen brothers to cash in on formulas that have proven profitable rather than letting them play.
Like in all of Smith's films, the dialogue is wonderful and realistic, but also consistent with Smith's other films, there are times when the momentum doesn't hold up.
Part infomercial, part historical documentary, all in 3-D, Nascar 3D is best seen as a spectacle, something that exists for its format rather than its content.
A sad portrait of one man's obsession with becoming someone he is not. Or is Flyerman the real Mark Vistorino? Either or, this is one legitimately tormented soul.

Although charming at times, My Date With Drew comes across as more than a little bit creepy given the present context of celebrity stalkers - not to mention the sight of a middle-aged man fawning over the portrait of a young child.
Full of potential smarts, failed intrigue and a dated survey of the 20th century.

Murderball doesn't want you to feel sorry for anyone. It wants the viewer to see them for who they are, not what they aren't. They're athletes with the same drive and passion for their sport as other athletes.
Combining horror and comedy isn't easy if you want to be taken seriously. Forest of the Dead tries but in the end it's a failure, even in the realm of low-budget filmmaking.
Since the story didn't draw me in too much I frequently found myself admiring the intricate scenery instead.
Equal parts horror and comedy, Return of the Living Dead finds success on both fronts.
