It's advisable to approach the movie without much prior knowledge: the tantalising reveal of connections between the characters is masterfully done.
A film set in an alternate reality must take time to establish the rules of its particular fiction, and most of the joys of The Lobster arise from these early scenes.
What the filmmakers fail to have noticed is that they have made most of the female characters unspeakably tedious, and given all the best moments to the men.
The film doesn't shake our suspicion that the stories being told have calcified into legend.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Unlike the baggy fabrics, the material is stretched a little thin.

Even fantasy needs verisimilitude, and if you're going to have your hero producing planes out of thin air, miles from any apparent airstrip, as Bond does, why stop there? Surely no need for a plane. Just have him zoom through the air, arms outstretched.

The stylistic palette of McQueen's picture, and its grasp of cinematic vocabulary, elevate the film to a purely visceral realm, so that it seems to bypass your eyes and ears and go straight for your nerve endings.

Shouldn't a Bond film worth the name be simply enjoyable? Even a chase that ends with Bond and his quarry crashing through a glass dome onto a pair of scaffolding towers... induces exhaustion rather than excitement.
A film that strips most of the glamour and escapism from Bond, but remains the truest and toughest instalment yet.
It's a hagiography. Malala undoubtedly deserves one. Audiences may crave something meatier.
This unpretentious drama knows its way.
It's not easy viewing by any means. But it is strangely refreshing for a movie to show us that terminal illness involves agony and vomit and terror, despite what Beaches might have told us.
The film, never less than visually magnificent, is almost entirely pointless: a shaggy-bear story at best.
Hail, Caesar! represents a breakthrough for the brothers as storytellers
The first 20 minutes of Remainder are ponderous, but once Tom begins to snap out of his daze the film wakes up, too.
The only mystery about Medem's new film, Ma Ma, is how a once-fascinating director could have made something so devoid of fibre or personality.
With the exception of John and Marilyn, faces are obscured, which feels right: why should we be allowed to see their son (or the actor playing him) when John has never seen him?
Though Absolutely Fabulous: the Movie bears many of the hallmarks of bad British sitcom cinema (floodlit lighting, echo-chamber sets), it is also barbed and appallingly funny in places.
This Ghostbusters also improves in every way on the original, which has been insulated for years by nostalgia.
The BFG succumbs to a fetishisation of luxury, the camera gawping in awe at the abundance of food and finery. It's almost as if it has forsaken the rich, repulsive gloop of the early scenes.
From Duggan's death all the way down to these casual domestic betrayals, the film has an acute sense of pain and injustice.
When there are lulls in the action, these are filled too often by homilies and life lessons that demand no spelling out.
Baron Cohen is mistaken if he thinks this eleventh-hour sweetener will make up for the previous hour or so of class libel.
As Kryptonite is to Superman, so cinema is to Ricky Gervais: on contact with it, he loses what it is that makes him special.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Gary Numan: Android in La La Land may be howlingly funny in places but it's no joke.
movie_title: Gary Numan: Android in La La Land (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [Allen] has so little faith in his cast that he outlines each character's feelings... before his actors have had a chance to work their magic. That is downright disrespectful when you have hired a collaborator as expressive as Stewart.
Almodóvar in plain-Jane mode is rather like any other director dressing up for the prom - he couldn't shoot a boring image if he tried.
The cast works diligently to find nuance in the material. They are no match, however, for a director who can't tell the difference between film-making and crowd-pleasing.
Shot with no particular finesse, it is often ungainly but rarely unappealing. Rather like Bridget, in fact.
It switches between so many points of view, we can't help wondering who has edited this "found" footage - and why their grasp of horror is so slack.
Sid and Nancy has some claim on being the finest British film of the 1980s.
Sachs captures the concentrated joy of youthful larks and loyalty but he is as wise as Fassbinder ever was to the impact of economic and social pressures on our emotional choices.
Dano is gentler than ever, Radcliffe agreeably deranged. Like all good relationships, it's a compromise. They make a lovely couple.

It sticks so faithfully to the conventions of the genre -- earthy blue-collar hero (Mark Wahlberg), worried wife fretting at home (Kate Hudson), negligent company man (John Malkovich) -- that familiarity overrides suspense and outrage.
The Girl on the Train is tabloid cinema: it gets the audience all juiced up on the very scenes of domestic violence and murder that it professes to deplore.
This is a film that thinks characterisation means having someone gaze sorrowfully at an old family photograph.
I'm swiping right on this one.
Just once it would be nice to have some character detail or a line of dialogue that went beyond "Suspect turning left", or the series catchphrase: "You don't have any idea who you're dealing with!"
Even documentaries need dramatic tension; this one is comprised solely of contented people being informed that their lives are tickety-boo. After a while, you can't take any Moore.
We get a hint that Guzmán is trying to find resonances where none naturally exist.
movie_title: The Pearl Button (El botón de nácar) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The adventure which ensues has as much nuttiness as you would expect, even if it lacks the innovative governing vision that Burton brought to the original.

It is the job of the modern superhero movie to explore at extravagant length and in morose detail the burden rather than the bliss of being one of the saviours of mankind, self-appointed or otherwise.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film scarcely draws a breath and nor do we.
All the groundwork in the world, though, can't alter the fact that a film which began in the style of Ken Loach has turned into Death Wish 3.
The shortcomings of Nicholls's movie help throw into sharp relief exactly what it was that Spielberg got so right.
The Brand New Testament is a fundamentally nice film but niceness is incompatible with the sort of black comedy it shows every sign of wanting to be.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The characters are multi-layered, crammed full of old allegiances and grudges and irritations. They have personalities. Remember those?
No one would start a punch-up if they said that the screenwriter Charlie Kaufman is the most original voice to emerge in US cinema since David Lynch.
No part of the production ever left the studio lot but you wouldn't know it. The density and detail of the jungle are rendered sensuously by digital effects experts.
Veronika Franz and Severin Fiala, the directors of Goodnight Mommy, leave no doubt that something is wrong. It is horribly enjoyable trying to work out what that might be.
This is an unusually honest portrayal of love as a system whereby two people can maintain one another's delusions to the point where they almost cease to be delusions at all.
Linklater is too besotted with his male creations to see that they can be divided almost without exception between the bland and the obnoxious. Even his usual eye for detail is a little off.

Baron Cohen is a refreshingly dark addition to the previous picture's candy-coloured world -- it's a nutty thrill to see him and Depp trying to out-weird one another in a scene in which Time is taunted with temporally-based wordplay.
[A] playful, haunting film.
I spent most of the movie wondering what the opposite was of eye-catching. Whatever it is, that's Warcraft.

Russell Crowe and Ryan Gosling represent polar opposites of movie masculinity. It's one of the reasons why their first film together, Shane Black's knowing comic thriller The Nice Guys, is such a pungent delight.
If anything, it's even better than The Commitments because it doesn't go in for the slick manipulation associated with that film's director, Alan Parker.
What Weerasethakul creates on-screen could be described as a meditative space: he is using film not to dictate his ideas but to stimulate ours.
Brown Willy shares its plot and themes with Kelly Reichardt's 2006 film Old Joy... But the picture has enough character and charm of its own.
[A] restrained, humane documentary.
Jamie and Crystal Fairy, though slightly exaggerated for comic effect, are still truer representations of gringo backpackers than I've ever seen on film.
The mysteries keep piling up through the final frames, when black-and-white film can't contain the story any longer and it bursts with unworldly color. You won't want to wake up.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The drug-addled camera and ominous music might seem excessive in Phillips' home office, but like a noisy refrigerator or odd smell, the body learns to ignore what's jarring at first.
This prequel delivers more levels than the Death Star's elevator.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: 'The Congress' widens the possibilities of filmmaking -- and in doing so, is as pro-cinema as it is anti-Hollywood.
Capture[s] the realities and rhythms of gay urban life without succumbing to the cliches that tend to plague queer cinema.
A nasty, insane, mind-melting and unpredictable piece of work
A sweet yet fleeting trifle.
The film's universe is one of complex moral fabric, where red herrings fall like flies and paranoia, among other things, is in the water.
Ten years after premiering at the Venice Film Festival in 2004, Jonathan Glazer's Birth remains as powerfully mysterious as ever.
We have Kechiche to thank for this wonderful movie that celebrates gay love (and sex) in all its messiness and truth.
An intimate, tres European, two-character piece free of easy moralism that ranks among the best debuts in recent memory.
The work of a master. This just isn't his masterpiece.
An engrossing documentary that lends humanity to independent pro wrestling's savage theater of machismo.
Underneath The Canyons' plastic deadness rattles a broken Lohan... And we really believe her.
Cinema loves its messed up mother-son relationships. But rarely are they handled with the mastery of Calin Peter Netzer's tale of smotherly love Child's Pose.
A nifty bit of murky fun rife with unsettling imagery and a sense of taut dread even Alfred Hitchcock would have admired.
Understands desire as something ravenous, terrifying and ridiculous.
'Volume II' showcases the filmmaker at his most confident, uncompromising and empathetic. Even if the film around her feels constructed, Joe is, finally, made of real flesh and blood.
A cinematic swoon.
Like good sci-fi, every element rings prescient, drawing upon our fears and anxieties as a species and a civilization.
A thriller brooding with disquiet and dread.
Not only is Our Sunhi pure pleasure through all its brisk running time, it is also a candid picture of male-female dynamics when one tries to upstage the other, in vain.
A low-budget sci-fi indie that doubles, and triples, and quadruples, as a truly original existential horror movie.
The trippiest historical horror film ever made?
Where Night Has Settled succeeds best is in the language, the left-unsaids and what-might-have-beens between characters, and in the disquieting textures of a too-close mother/son relationship.

An intimate epic as fresh and thrillingly alive as Francois Truffaut's films of Antoine Doinel, who was wrought in five movies beginning with The 400 Blows. Boyhood is but one movie, and it's just as subversive.
"Applause" is a very minor film with a massive performance at its center.
Low-key but effectively eerie.
6 Years has universal appeal in spades, two lovely lead performances and a whole lot of truth.
The first hour offers a textured, specific and creepy study of female victimhood and unspeakable trauma. And then the director loses his mind.
Mia Hansen-Løve's EDM movie memoir is the art-house party of the year.
Meyerhoff's scrapbook style will irritate some, and enrapture others. But in a world of increasingly stentorian female filmmakers, she's one to watch.
For those cinephiles who go weak at the knees for tortured artists and decadents, it's movie heaven.
A startlingly audacious departure for the writer/director that also feels like a natural progression for an auteur in the making.
A warm, winning female buddy comedy that turns the genre on its head in gently surprising ways.
'Evolution of a Criminal' is a documentary and a provocation, a movie and a bitter truth to swallow.

Chastain's electrifying performance places among the great female dramatic turns in a literary tragedy, from Nina Pens Rode in 'Gertrud' to Nastassja Kinski in 'Tess' and Isabelle Huppert in 'Madame Bovary.'
'Kids for Cash' will scare the wits out of anyone worried about how institutional neglect is affecting our kids.

A must-see for fans of extreme cinema and those movie-lovers who get off on taut editing, delicately placed sound design and tightly wound storytelling-and a must-never-see for pretty much everybody else.

Araki's beautifully told films make you feel warm and fuzzy... revealing a latent darkness that leaves you unsafe and unsettled. And these warring sensibilities have never felt more at odds (or at home) than in the campy, creeping dread of 'White Bird.'
Gruesomely funny.
Part existential murder mystery, part Freudian detective story and fully an indictment of the American success story.
A depressingly bad and soulless seriocomedy.
Marques-Marcet's lovely debut opens with an impressively staged single take that manages to convey the entire universe of a longterm relationship in just 23 minutes.
A steady of stream of data is nothing compared to the individual stories this documentary tells, and how Nation contextualizes these problems within greater historical trends.
Gemini is a deeply enjoyable, satisfyingly subversive and uniformly well crafted modern noir mystery. You don't want to miss this one.
Wish Upon is a mess from initial premise, let alone its direction and editing - not even Hitchcock himself could've saved this one.
t may not be as polished as its other drama-romance counterparts, but Beast is a bold, ambitious debut from Pearce.
Don't Sleep probably won't be making any waves of any form any time soon. It's frequently so underwhelming that it crosses over into being flat out boring.
The Layover was never going to be a comedy classic, though it has all the ingredients to make for a fun, funny 80 minutes, but it never quite gets there.
Even if most of Pilgrimage doesn't feel like the film it should be, it remains enjoyable viewing.
The Persian Connection is bold, tense, and thrilling, even if its thematic reach just exceeds its grasp.
There's undeniably more good in Six Rounds than bad, but the film would benefit from a bit more focus and a more accessible emotional core.
Miss Sloane is well performed and it's gripping for the entirety of its two hours, even if its final twist is less effective in afterthought than it is in the moment.
A Woman's Life is a good film. But I wouldn't recommend it. Films that are unremittingly bleak are fine, as long as they have a point to make.
The Dark Tapes is fun, scary and consistently tense - it knows exactly what kind of film it wants to be and isn't afraid to simply roll with it.
Ultimately, Departure doesn't do anything that hasn't been done before, and what it does do isn't enough for us to overlook that.
Don't Hang Up is a fun and mostly effective little horror that holds your interest, it just doesn't say as much as its premise suggests.
Don't Think Twice a funny film about very funny people, but finds areas in life that aren't funny and shows the impact that it can have on even the most unexpected people.
Loveless definitely lives up to its title. This is a cold, calculated, emotionally distant film that has little to no interest of making you like any of its characters.
The Autopsy Of Jane Doe's premise is jaw-droppingly exciting, but it soon gives way to ticking off every horror cliche in the book.
Battle of the Sexes is a well crafted film, and it's potentially the most crowd pleasing feature you'll see all year, but it just lacks the oomph to fall firmly into greatness.
As a 90 minute character study, Tiger Girl works nicely. Vanilla's slow descent from goody two shoes into something more animalistic is handled well by both director and actress.
The Lovers is a fleetingly enjoyable film, but it's not one I'd recommend for anything more than a middling, easy 90 minutes that requires little to no brainpower.
Wonderstruck is a beautiful film from its opening frame right to its last, and it takes you on a powerful, emotional story between them.
Brawl in Cell Block 99 is a thrillingly unique film experience in just how far it's willing to stretch its violence before you have to turn away.
I wasn't enamoured by Call My By Your Name until its final half hour, by which point I was swept away in a sea of love, longing and, ultimately, loss.
Undeniably essential viewing.
This is a gleefully daring film that grips from the first frame, even if it takes its time to unleash the extent of what its truly subjecting you to.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Linklater has served up another classic.
The Party is a very funny film, and a great deal of that comes from Clarkson.
Downsizing is engaging and well acted enough to warrant your investment.
There's a general lack of energy and identity to Small Town Crime, so much so that it's tough not to become frustrated by how bland the film is.
Del Toro has struck gold with The Shape of Water.
In Greta Gerwig's directorial debut she's landed on something great, a film that takes on something we've all seen before but in such a complex way that it feels entirely new again.
Breathe's story is undeniably a powerful one, and it's a story we'd perhaps all be better off knowing, but as a film this doesn't really leap off the screen.
Three Billboards is one of those films that comes along only once every decade or so.
The Light of the Moon isn't a film you forget easily. It takes on a global issue and acts as if it's something small, resulting in a film that feels both vitally important and imminently personal.
It lacks the conviction to be anything more than an effects driven extravaganza and any attempt at metaphorical work or character building is offensively uninspired.
While "Detroit" may try and cover too much ground and occasionally stumble on its ambition, the sheer visceral power of Kathryn Bigelow's direction is worth championing.

Surprisingly, Roth's film has more in common with "RoboCop" than Winner's original, but in chasing after that level of prestigious trash, this version of "Death Wish" sets itself up for lofty goals that it can't quite achieve.
The film's focus on happiness, the ways it visualizes and verbalizes the multiple meanings and practices of happiness, should be received by Americans as a welcome surprise.
It's probably best to stick with the games.
Psychologically thrilling, yet oddly and darkly comic at times, Faults is an intense character study that gets under your skin and sends chills up your spine.

It reinvents the franchise in a bold and mature way, while never losing sight of the campy fun that made Power Rangers so beloved to begin with, and for that alone, that makes this movie a worthwhile surprise.
As it stands, this version is still an enjoyably solid watch, but it's just not the ambitious masterpiece that it could've been.

Logan is as understated a masterpiece as there's ever been, delivering the Wolverine film we've all been waiting for, and if this truly is Hugh Jackman's final time playing him, he has definitely left the series on a high note.

This will probably not be to everyone's tastes considering the film's uncomfortable nature and the lack of clarity within the narrative, but this film offers a unique experience that'll leave you surprised and intrigued.
Not just a bona fide masterpiece, but also the best film of the year bar none, capturing the true nature of Hollywood and Los Angeles in a way that's both unconventional and surprising.
The unsatisfying storytelling and the fact that we should expect more from this beloved franchise ... makes this somewhat disappointing.
Kelly Fremon Craig [has created] what is a true gem of a movie that has the hallmarks of a bonafide cult classic, which proves that she's truly a talent to watch out for.
The fact that Patricio Valladares just went for it and thrown so many enticing ingredients into an already spicy soup is commendable and that makes the film more enjoyable than it sounds
In the end, 400 Days is a good and compelling idea that has been disappointingly realised with a preposterous second half.
It is one of the worst films of 2016, and while it is entertaining, the entertainment factor is completely unintentional.
As far as independent short films go, this is one of the better ones out there.

Momentum is in the end silly, trashy B-movie nonsense, yet it's top quality trash of the highest order as it does what it sets out to do by being enjoyably entertaining and having a stylistic gloss to its visuals.
There is fun to be found, but when is all said and done, the eyes may be sated, but the brain's still craving.

Edgar Wright has been an influential presence in cinema and once again, he delivers in spades with Baby Driver rocketing upwards into the higher echelons as one of the best films to come out of this year.

With all its faults, The Osiris Child is still a solid movie that shows the potential for what can be possible in Australian cinema, just as long as you have the passion, ambition and creativity driving it.
movie_title: The Osiris Child: Science Fiction Volume One (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets is absolute nonsense like no other ... but with an actual sense of humour. It's beautifully realised, highly imaginative and creative, yet has goofy performances and a script that revels in its cheesiness.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie may be silly, stupid and ridiculous, but it's incredibly creative with its humour, animation, characters and story that its silliness makes it all part of its charm.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: No matter what you make of it, Red Sparrow is an odd, peculiar beast of a movie that, like its main protagonist, you don't really know what to make of it.
This film feels like watching a series of fight sequences that are loosely connected by a wafer thin plot.
This is still a solid LEGO movie with a great voice cast.

This movie makes you question what you would do if something this tragic happened to you, and how you would cope being this invisible, disembodied entity who can do nothing except watch life pass you by, and that rationalization is scary to imagine.
As a film, House is still as much of a warm, at times bonkers, family-friendly horror as it's ever been.

House II doesn't quite have anything similar to the strong performance of the original's Bill Katt anchoring the picture, but it still has plenty to make it a worthwhile follow-up that's definitely worth watching.
Despite its flaws, Sweet Virginia is a suspense-filled, tension-built thriller with a palpable sense of dread and gloom felt throughout that adds to the strong performances, as well as the drama.
In the end, Justice League is an enjoyable fun, if severely flawed movie that is better than the first three entries in the DCEU, but falls short of Wonder Woman's heights.

What Paddington 2 demonstrates is that in the currently messed-up and hectic world we currently live in, we need films like this to remind us how we need something loving to make our lives endearing, akin to the warm message of It's a Wonderful Life.

Like all of his movies, Stanley Kubrick's direction is simply astonishing in every frame; from the warped angles to the eerie motion and surreal atmosphere, it just all adds to the disturbing, deranged environment/mindscape Kubrick's trying to create.
Despite its flaws, Wonder Woman is every bit as epic as Batman v. Superman or Suicide Squad, yet has the humanity and emotion that those movies sorely lacked, despite being smaller-scaled.

Belle de Jour is a film that's ambiguous and alluring in equal measure, and while that can be alienating for modern audiences, this is a film that is still radical, thought provoking and enticing after 50 years.
For the most part, Atomic Blonde is an atomic blast, delivering on the action and allure with style and panache. Theron is one cool action badass.

This movie's ultimate achievement is remembering what a great Spider-Man movie should always be in the end: fun, heartfelt, and exciting without ever losing sight of what makes the character so beloved and iconic.
Perhaps worst of all are the limited expectations Coppola has for her own heroine. It's hard to love a movie where a woman finds herself from the passenger seat.

While teenage tropes are dutifully checked off - the love triangle, the makeover, the party gone wrong - there's originality to Nadine's lonely quest to find her place, only to ultimately learn she's not alone in being all alone.
Like the villain of Split, Shyamalan's worst enemy just might be himself.
When Hollywood casts a dog as the lead in a movie, it's pretty much always because there is a sappily inspirational tale to be told. And that, as they say, is A Dog's Purpose.
You can picture the pitch: if you sort-of liked Power Rangers when it was half recycled footage, wait until you see a version that costs over a hundred million dollars!
While the footage is breathtaking, these animal tales get wobblier every year at walking the line between educational fun and hard-to-swallow stories of animals acting out human narratives.
Jacobs has delivered a two-handed character study and, in this mission, he is handily assisted by his two powerful leads.
The Black Prince may follow the formula of a prestige pic, but this messy film just shows why those truly stirring historical dramas deserve the awards season glory they get.
The best horror movies leave the most frightening elements to an audience's imagination. Leatherface is not one of those movies.
Amy Jo Johnson reaches for big laughs and deep feels that prove beyond her grasp in her feature directorial debut.
Muschietti's It strikes a nice balance between sleepover-ready gross-outs (tiptoeing through raw sewage, for example) and tender coming-of-age storytelling.
This would be boring if it wasn't so unintentionally funny.
Most of the film feels like an exercise in creating enough plot to hit the 90-minute mark.

What makes Death Day feel so fresh is that this is all played with a whopper of a wink, pulled off by the considerable comedic talents of star Jessica Rothe, who successfully juggles the horror/comedy mash-up.
Rothe was a standout in last year's horror comedy Happy Death Day, but the Denver-born actor's performance here as Josie is as coolly bland as overnight oats.
Though each of these great actors are somewhere on the spectrum of being funny, no one feels completely in their element.

What the film lacks in actual music and performance (only a snippet of Beyoncé's "Formation"?), it makes up for in intimate interviews with the Lethal Ladies and their mothers, who are doing their best to give their daughters a better life.
Some variety of acacia are also known as being spiny and this film is certainly no smooth, care-free affair.
Saw II is a stronger film than its predecessor.
A movie inspired by a video game inspired by a broad range of action/horror flicks. The snake is eating its own tail again. We've seen this trick before.
TV episode review - This is a great exploitation piece. One with a weak script, some broad characterizations, and choice cop dialogue
Rec 2 juggles a fresh approach while placating those who are looking for the same unyielding attitude of the first film.

It's a mesmerizing companion piece to films like the underappreciated My Little Eye -- and most recently Vacancy -- that comments on the technological advancements we've made to satiate and manipulate the human condition.
One of the best horror films I've seen in years.
You never get the sense that Del Toro's flourishes are egotistical excess. It's just part of the world he has created. It's organic.
An emotionally tone deaf and, typical of the director, gimmick-laden and aggressively polished adaptation.
When 17 Again isn't pilfering from its betters, it's engaging in the most Pavlovian button-pushing.
Riklis is ultimately unable to center his attention on any one of its multiple fissures and reflexively allows Lemon Tree to rest on its aura of subliminal female solidarity.
It's all in good fun, even if it isn't actually much fun.
A romance aiming at a tone of jazz-riff larkishness but somewhat undermined in that pursuit by the washboard-stiffness of its main characters.
The International isn't pitching itself at Jack Ryan territory, but weirdly, at The Da Vinci Code.
He's Just Not That Into You can't help but approximate its unsatisfying elevation of chit-chat into a primary mode of rom-com narrative communication, a bad omen for the genre going forward.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Hiistorical events referenced in the first two installments of the Underworld franchise are brought to life in this passionless, idea-deprived prequel.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A half-assed re-filming of First Blood.
What sets the film a notch above standard genre fare is its ability to ask bigger questions about a stalker like Doug.
Leatherheads isn't poorly made, but it's easy, hang-back material from a director who's already proven himself up for a challenge, and that's hard to accept.

Drillbit Taylor presents nothing blindingly new for fans of Apatow- or Sandler-style humor and when watching it, one can hear the faint rustling of old scripts being yanked from drawers for a timely cash-in.

I can't recommend it as a good movie on its own merits, stocked as it is with cardboard cutout characters and a barely coherent plot, but it's miles more interesting than the last Alien vs. Predator film
A depressing, static drama that will have heads lolling backwards and eyes drooping wherever it plays.
This is a film with a lot of big emotions, but not a lot of big moments.
One of the most ill-conceived films to come down the pike in a long, long time.
The long-awaited directorial debut of Alan Ball does not disappoint.

Works on every level -- the performances are compelling, the drama feels grounded and real, and we brush up against an issue so large and overwhelming that you can easily see why no one thinks it's their problem to solve.
Not as profound in its revelations as it wants to be, but with strong acting and a strong visual palette, it's a success.
Sometimes charming, occasionally funny, it never draws attention to itself as the work of a director with training wheels on.

I tend to think that even bad De Palma -- movies like Snake Eyes and The Black Dahlia -- are still better than most of the tripe we have to sit through, so even if Redacted falls under that category, it's still worth recommending.
A film torpedoed by its own self-indulgence.
Chalk up another stunning achievement for Joe Wright, who must now be recognized as an auteur with few equals of his age and experience in world cinema.

Those going into this film expecting some kind of corollary to Foster's other film about random violence, The Accused, will be disappointed for the simple reason that that was a serious film, and this is not.
Like the human skulls crushed under sleek metal feet in those feverish sequences, the Terminator film series is finished.

The penetrating musical score, with its memorable shadings of emotional danger, the snappy and confident pacing and the emergence of 33-year-old Labaki as an international talent to watch all combine to make the film satisfying confection.
A giddy procession of intermittently successful jump scares and make-you-vomit sight gags strung together by a story so elemental it could be rendered in mural form on a funhouse wall.
An incessantly talky, inert crime film that's like a hip-hop poseur, all swagger and mouth but with no real taste for the grittiness of thug life.
In consistently erring of the side of subtlety, Moreau's performance also proves a perfect tonal match for Provost's subtle, meticulous, and frequently beautiful compositions.
Annihilation gets momentum from the deeper it pushes into the uncertainties of ecology and the self.
A shot that defiantly fixes on Mel Gibson's balding pate from behind is the only evidence of the volatile actor-director's famous penchant for cinematic self-flagellation here.
