movie_review_blurb: The movie slips into a familiar rut and the scenery fades into the background.
The movie doesn't quite extract blood, sweat, or tears, even if it does toil.
It's a film of genuine beauty, one where you come away as eager to talk about the set design and the choreography as you do the fate of the galaxy or what might happen next.
[Liam] Neeson lands plenty of punches, but the movie works best when he's fighting shadows or fighting himself.

The world is not so full of beauty that one can wave away Mary's visual majesty, especially now that its hand-drawn style is nearly a thing of the past. But the flaws in its writing are harder to overlook.
It's a reminder that as much as a film can open doors, there are places we're allowed into only by the grace of our hosts, and that permission can be withdrawn at any moment.
It's a horror movie one moment, a comedy the next, as if Netflix were streaming several different titles at once.

Whatever its obvious limitations, the gambit of casting nonactors in the lead roles at least brings the movie a certain authenticity, but it's torpedoed by the tin-eared backstory laid out by Dorothy Blyskal's script.

If you've already devoured the Wallace and Gromit canon, as well as Chicken Run and Shaun the Sheep, Early Man is a wonderful way of extending their giddy glow, even if it feels like a small step backward.
It's like watching a magician spend several minutes on elaborate flourishes and then drawing your card from a deck of one.

The back and forth between McAdams and Bateman is what makes Game Night sing (which is not to slight Horgan's dry wit or Magnussen's elegant idiocy or Morris' magnificent Denzel Washington impression).

The movie's biggest mistake is indulging conventional horror-movie reality, where characters live or die according to their fortitude and our sense of the world's rightness is conservatively reaffirmed.
Drives home an oft-observed truth with wit and style. It's thin, but then so is a knife between your ribs.
Barry is the closest thing Tom Cruise has played to a regular Joe in more than a decade, and the part isn't a snug fit.
Its characters are largely new, which means the movie can do with them as it wants. It isn't hemmed in the way most prequels are.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Allied is technically immaculate from stem to stern. Every shot framed by Don Burgess feels purposeful, every one of Mick Audsley and Jeremiah O'Driscoll's cuts precise.

The movie could have examined the limitations of white liberalism, the damage that well-meaning people can do if they don't educate themselves along the way. Instead, it embodies that well-meaning approach, and all the harm it can do.

If Bad Santa does well at the box office, Zwigoff will get credit for being a savvy player. That Bad Santa is as vile and stupid as Ghost World was insightful and touching is something Hollywood has no interest in measuring.
Shot in lurid colors and drizzled with a squelchy synthesizer score, Adam Wingard's bloody thriller is so enamored of John Carpenter it might as well be passing him mash notes in social studies.
The scariest thing you'll see this Halloween is Edward Snowden swearing in disbelief at the end of Laura Poitras' gripping, disturbing documentary.
Slate, who had a brief and unremarkable tenure on Saturday Night Live, proves a winning companion; it's a hang-out movie, and she's fun to hang out with.
Chicago may not rank with the classics, but it's the best traditional movie musical in many a moon.
Gigli won't be the worst movie to come out of Hollywood all year, but it's sure to be one of the most forgettable.
X2 still feels like a prologue. No matter how much goes on, you feel like nothing has happened.
Leni Riefenstahl's infamous masterwork sits with The Birth of a Nation in the pantheon's "outcast unclean" section.
movie_title: Triumph des Willens (Triumph Of The Will) (1935)

movie_review_blurb: Not surprisingly, the movie lives and dies on Steen's performance; not only is she in almost every frame, but at times, the camera is in so close that nothing is visible but her pitted, ravaged face.
As winsome, Sundance-ready rom-coms go, "Maggie's Plan" is a pretty winning one.
Perhaps the scariest thing about it is the realization that if the fate of the world depends on well-meaning issue docs, then we really are doomed.

We cry not because the movie has tapped into our deepest hopes and fears, but because this is the part where we're supposed to. Dory's catchphrase is "Just keep swimming," but the movie feels like it's just paddling in circles.
Mother's great feat is that it's a movie that manages to be both exploitative and progressive.
movie_title: Mother, May I Sleep with Danger? (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It might be time to let Tarzan vanish back into the jungle.
Gibney's movies are professional and solidly executed, informative if you go in underinformed but rarely surprising or aesthetically noteworthy.
"Hillary's America" isn't designed to stand up to skepticism. It's not intended to convince or to provoke thought, but to confirm the biases its intended audience already holds.
movie_title: Hillary's America: The Secret History of the Democratic Party (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The impetus to tune out the movie's words only makes it easier to feast your eyes on its breathtaking images, which after a summer of underlit glop feel like a tall glass of cool water.
With Arrival, Villeneuve finally finds a subject, and a script, whose magnitude matches the weight he assigns to it. All it took was an alien species' appearance on Earth.
The performances are so deliberate and overworked they might as well have the script tattooed on their faces.
Proceeds like a real-life thriller, one with striking parallels to its narrative contemporary Deepwater Horizon.
The work of a major film-maker and not just a promising one.
It's an intellectual experience rather than an emotional one, but the ideas in play are so heady they're enough to sweep you away on their own.
For the work of a 74-year-old veteran director, the movie feels dispiritingly juvenile, more like the fantasy of a frightened boy than a film-making great.
It's far too soon for a happy ending, but in praising Kato's bravery, Call Me Kuchu at least points to the potential for one.
It's pleasant and honourable, and it makes a worthwhile point. But it's strangely lacking in urgency, a period piece that never breaks out of its period.
Notwithstanding its oddball premise, Colossal feels far too familiar, one more foot-dragging drama about a 30-something screwup wrestling with her darker impulses.

Directors in their later years often settle comfortably into their preoccupations, doodling happily around the edges of their previous careers. Verhoeven is still trying to make masterpieces, and with Elle, he comes awfully close.
Woods can't even bring herself to make Leah any worse than naive, if sometimes dangerously so, which makes White Girl less complex and sophisticated than an average episode of Girls.
It's more engrossing to just hang out with the characters in all their damaged glory, before the plot marches through the room with its clunkiest boots on.

One might question why a simple first-date story needs to involve the future president and first lady, but its near-total lack of precursors suggest that if it weren't about one of the most famous black couples, it would likely not have been made at all.
If it had half the segments, and they were twice as long, the movie might be able to get beneath the surface and find the monomaniacal characters Herzog is often so great at exploring.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This film glosses over the thorniest issues in play -- both in terms of the US government's actions and the unintended consequences of Snowden's disclosures -- and settles for a safe, familiar account of one man standing up against the system.
Mayer doesn't find a way to make the ritual traumas of adolescence feel new again.
Miyazaki isn't interested in the jolts of surrealism so much as imbuing his audience with the idea that reality can change at any moment, and change back just as quickly.
The structural fireworks of Darcy-Smith's first feature may ultimately provide more light than heat, but they don't distract unduly from its strong performances.
The Road spends most of its time going in circles, working and reworking a small set of potent images.
Portrait Of Wally tells a gripping story, but the filmmakers should have been more forthright about their own part in it.
Jackson seems only interested in cashing his paycheck, even if it's not an especially large one.
Sy and Cluzet give their parts more conviction than they deserve, even when the former is forced to re-enact the falsetto-singing-in-the-bubblebath bit from Pretty Woman.
Black seems to be aiming for some sort of loopy fantasia, a tragic fable about struggling with difference in the small-town South, but he's got more half-finished ideas than he can handle.
This drama styles itself as a cinematic epic, but its substance is as flimsy as a Jack Chick pamphlet.
While it's fascinating to observe the workings of the mammoth apparatus grafted onto an intensely personal decision, the movie's heart is the moments that take place in private.

Given that Henriksson is in his 20th hour of playing Wallander onscreen, it's no surprise that his performance has a well-worn ease; like the character himself, he seems to have been doing this his whole life.
Madagscar 3 is less interested in plucking the last bit of meat off the series's bones than with simply picking the lowest-hanging fruit.
Substituting charm, and sometimes quirk, for special effects, the no-budget time-travel caper Safety Not Guaranteed squeaks by on goodwill and guarded expectations.
Unlike any of the sequels between it and the original, Prometheus is a horror movie first and foremost, gnawing at subconscious terrors even as your conscious mind attempts to bat it away.
The heart of any concert movie is the concert itself, and in the case of Neil Young Journeys, it's a great one.
Sherman's feature turns out to be enamored of the kind of reality that gets left out of movies not because it's provocative or controversial, but because it isn't particularly interesting.
For a movie that spends so much time extolling the virtues of the imagination to show so little of its own is more than ironic -- it's offensive.

Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne make great movies with such regularity they can be easy to overlook, but The Kid With a Bike puts just enough spin on the Dardennes' formula to let you feel their worth anew.
Continental Drift feels less like an extension of a theatrical franchise than an episode of a middling TV cartoon, lolling around on territory that's already been settled.
[González] keeps his distance, leaving room for plenty of thoughtfully framed compositions and allowing the hush of a dried-up land to predominate.
"2 Days in Paris" is as self-assured as it is slight, a deliberate diversion whose winsome charms never run dry.
At times, as Ewing and Grady's cameras prowl its empty streets, the city seems like the world's largest ghost town.
A poignant case study in the changing contours of gay life.
It's an uncomplicated single-character study whose main purpose is as a housing for its lead performance.
It's not a satisfying whole, but parts are sheer delight.
The Master is less than the sum of its parts, but, oh, what parts they are.
A Judge Dredd for the 21st century: humorless, scowling and shot in murky 3-D.
A crushing disappointment by almost any standard, Marjane Satrapi and Vincent Parronaud's followup to the delightful Persepolis is a bad idea poorly realized.
The sequences blur together into something resembling a tourist-office promo.
A toothless, insufferably smug satire using competitive butter-carving as a weak-tea stand-in for Midwestern politics ...
Follows through on its yuckster premise with uncommon insight and dedication, without a shirk or a smirk.

The doc's technique of cutting between warm exchanges and the bellicose rhetoric of then-presidents Ahmadinejad and Bush wears thin with overuse, but the big-hearted Sheppard makes for an amiable tour guide.
That War of the Buttons shows no insight into how a nation's will could be so easily subdued is disappointing; that it shows no curiosity on the subject is inexcusable.
movie_title: La nouvelle guerre des boutons (War of the Buttons) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Chen can't seem to decide whether he's making a fable or something more down-to-earth, but Sacrifice works either way, if not both at once.
The power of Middle Of Nowhere is cumulative, conveyed in sustained tone and deepening character rather than bravura sequences or explosive confrontations.
Terence Davies doesn't make movies so much as he makes moods, languorous explorations of time and space that coalesce like a cloud of fragrant smoke.
Sound of My Voice has great atmosphere, but it signifies less than it could.
Come Back, Africa is a work of amazing grace-and a forgotten treasure.
Heigl's comic timing is solid, and she knows her limitations well enough, but there's a hollowness at the movie's center, right where Heigl's heart should be.
Close can't keep the character from seemingly like a pitiable doormat, but the tears come nonetheless.
The characters are deliberately ordinary, but their stories take on the weight of myth.
It's one of few animated fairy tales to genuinely transport the audience into their world and, in the process, let us see our own with fresh awe and respect.
Cirkus Columbia looks to the past, evoking the kind of unreal, vaguely politicized tales that were once the lifeblood of arthouse cinema.
A slow-motion car crash of miscalculated charisma, BuzzKill lives and rapidly dies by Daniel Raymont's grating lead performance.
By Perry's standards, it's a high-toned production, which means it doesn't look as if were shot during downtime on a soap-opera set, but it's still as blurry as a fifth-generation copy.
Black Butterflies scarcely tries to illuminate the substance of Jonker's writing.
The fact that Last Days Here cares more about Liebling's personal redemption than his professional triumph is ultimately a saving grace, a telling demonstration of the film's well-ordered priorities.
The film's antipodean locales provide plenty of uncharted territory, vast expanses of untamed land that offer endless opportunity but little guidance. A man could get lost out there, and Wallis does.
Nicolas Cage has spent so long turning himself into a living cartoon that he's lost the ability to play human beings.
It's a rebound-romance movie that's simplistic but sweet, an uncomplicated cinematic bonbon.
Kaye frequently flirts with familiar tropes, but here, he takes them in a loving embrace, betraying a rank sentimentality the film otherwise avoids.
Rolleston's winning presence doubtless has much to do with the fact that Boy is a record-breaking hit in its home country, but there's some salt mixed in with the film's sugar.
[Dorff] spends most of the movie confusing tough-guy stoicism with simple inertness, despite the occasional Jack Bauer-style yell.
The mechanics of the pending cataclysm don't interest Ferrera so much as the emotional stakes: How do people act when there's no future left?
Physical superiority and popularity are no longer prerequisites for grinding someone else down, which makes understanding bullying as essential as stigmatizing it. We are all bullies now.
Dafoe invests every action with a sense of purpose (not, thankfully, the same thing as meaning), to the extent that viewers would likely turn up to watch him peel potatoes, Jeanne Dielman-style.
Stillman too often substitutes pith for insight, until even that is drowned out by the sound of him chortling into his sleeve.
Touchback takes a handoff from Peggy Sue Got Married and It's A Wonderful Life and runs it up the middle for a modest gain.
One moment Dreier is proclaiming his regret, the next he's drawing a bankrupt analogy between fictional bank robbers and the crimes he committed in "so-called reality."
"Life, Love, Soul" has its heart in the right place. Unfortunately, nothing else is.
For all the hardware involved, To the Arctic's ultra-high-def images have an oddly plastic sheen.
A winsome, though clunky, romance mercifully sidelines the obvious symbolism...
Like 21 Grams minus the breadth, acting, or visual style, Aimee Lagos' first feature follows two pairs of friends on a collision course.
Headhunters' title rapidly turns literal, and what seemed like a lightweight heist thriller careens into a bloody-minded game of cat and mouse.

It's hard to swallow Statham, who spent the Crank movies supercharging his last minutes of life, as a suicidal sad-sack, just as it's painful to see him yoked to a cute little girl in an obvious attempt to soften his image.
Turner seems stifled by the joyless role of a woman whose only purpose is to be taught the error of her sanctimonious ways.
It's true that Americans contribute disproportionately to the problem, but catering to the idea that we're separate from the rest of the world isn't part of the solution.
Hall's puppy-dog charisma holds up under the strain, but it isn't nearly enough to keep this messy midlife-crisis dramedy afloat.
It barely tries to offer insight into its much-debated subject, content to rip the scab off an ever-fresh wound for the sake of controversy.
More inspirational than informative, which is not to slight the importance of inspiring similar movements.
Crude as it is, The Call milks its jump scares and don't-go-down-to-the-basement tension for all they're worth. See it with a full house, if you absolutely must see it at all.
The Sapphires might pass muster as escapist fluff, but its pretensions of significance go woefully awry.
Like a Rand Paul rally rendered in the style of Grand Theft Auto, Silver Circle engineers the perfect marriage of sub-par animation and sloppy thinking.
Clutching Jack Kerouac's peripatetic roman à clef like a besotted sophomore, Walter Salles trails Kerouac and Neal Cassady's novelistic doppelgängers like an eager puppy.
Everybody Has a Plan isn't overburdened so much as stretched pitifully thin, and the double-the-fun result is closer to the dueling-Elvises vehicle Kissin' Cousins than, say, Dead Ringers.
Petzold handles personal, formal and political concerns in such harmony that it's difficult, and not especially desirable, to separate one from the next.
A canny comedy and cutting critique, Pablo Larraín's No looks back at the 1980 vote to extend or end Chilean autocrat Augusto Pinochet's rule through an adman's eyes.
Works mostly as a mood piece, but what a mood it is.
Artistic inspiration can be close to madness, but Mental is just plain nuts.
So redolent of adolescent fantasy, you can practically hear a 12-year-old shouting "Blam!"
Unlike most awards-grubbing biopics, this one feels no need to telegraph its own difficulty.
[Trapero is] as thoughtful and perceptive a filmmaker as ever, using tools appropriate to the goal of drawing attention to systemic social ills.
Potter's take on the '60s occasionally slides into Big Chill cliché, but with her actors, she's on virgin ground.
Mungiu works in long takes and at a measured pace, burying the story's true-crime origins for half the film's two-and-a-half-hour length.
The film feels like it's over long before the credits roll-or perhaps that's just wishful thinking.
Divorce it from awards-season hype, and Argo holds up fine: There's no need to pretend it's something it's not, when what it is works just fine.
In spite of its attention-grabbing opening and provocative title, Free Angela And All Political Prisoners is less a work of agitprop than straightforward history, intriguing but never unsettling.
Malick doesn't reach for the sublime so much as lunge, arms outstretched, face turned to the sky. He stumbles, but still, it's a beautiful fall.
A cracking thriller built around art auctioneer James McAvoy' convenient amnesia, Danny Boyle's Trance jumps the rails in the closing stretch.
It's easy to roll your eyes at the film's overreach, but every movie should be so flawed
When Nair tries to take in the larger picture, her focus goes slack, and all that's left is a blur.

Although Heyerdahl's book about the expedition became an international bestseller, and the documentary he directed on the same subject won an Oscar, the anthropology field has remained stubbornly unmoved. But in Kon-Tiki, the dream is all that matters.
Generation Um... devolves into a heap of sub-American Beauty profundities and strained confessionals ...
Great stories don't always make for great documentaries, although it's easy to confuse the two.
It fails to bring much insight to what essentially amounts to a massive parental guilt trip.
A decade behind the times.
movie_title: And Now A Word From Our Sponsor (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Ricky Jay is the master of a discipline he created: trickster, archivist, showman and raconteur rolled into one.
movie_title: Deceptive Practice: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Dumps the fill-in-the-blanks structure for straightforward comic action. Unfortunately, the impetus has less to do with a push for novelty than simple franchise fatigue.
So generic it might as well come in a black-and-white box: Animated Adventure TBD.
Works with a light touch, but leaves a surprisingly lasting mark.
Bahrani shares his characters' ambitions, and also their lack of perspective.
No Place On Earth mixes present-day interviews with re-enactments that illustrate the speakers' words without adding much to them.
The world the characters inhabit is less expressionist than impressionist, blessed with a delicate evocation of natural light and color that subtly incorporates Miyazaki's environmentalism.
Sticking to what's on the page pays off, especially with regard to Roth's undervalued late novels, but also means he has [the filmmakers] just where he wants them.
Shows a different side of the Japanese animation house, one that finds equal wonder in comparatively mundane affairs.

Self-consciously cribbing from Chekhov by way of Robert Altman, the filmmaker convenes an extended family of stage actors at a decaying country house in New Rochelle, where the Ambien-enhanced emotional pitch lingers north of perpetual hysteria.
Set and shot in post-U.S.-liberation Afghanistan, The Black Tulip is noteworthy for its existence alone-and not, unfortunately, for much else.
A movie of big ideas, and only some of them are terrible.
Starts with an irresistibly trashy premise and proceeds to treat it with the po-faced pretentiousness of a film-school thesis.
Zilberman is breaking no new ground, but he gives his actors strong material and room to breathe. When the playing is strong enough, even a few notes can be as rich as a symphony.
A Man's Story never gets its man.
Zemeckis focuses on surfaces but never discovers what lies beneath them.
Rings a few welcome changes on the Disney-princess mythos, but it still feels like a game you've played before.
At least for a while, Arcel manages to animate the long-settled debate, at least until the inevitability of its resolution becomes too clear to overlook.
The most eloquent episode of Schoolhouse Rock ever made.
It's clever and cute and never lets you forget it, winning in spite of how much it insists on it.
Many reissues claim the mantle of lost masterpiece, but Wake in Fright is the genuine article.
There's not much to dislike in My Brothers' sweet inconsequence, but even less to quicken the pulse or stir the heart.
Lewy's film functions largely as a delivery system for Carlyle's performance. Luckily, Carlyle's tough, tender turn is strong enough to carry the load.
Essentially an MTV Cribs episode padded out to feature length, Andy Capper's obsequious doc shadows Snoop Dogg-now Snoop Lion-during the making of his first reggae album.

From its flash-forward framing sequence to its glossy black and white images, the film emulates Raging Bull in nearly every particular, while failing to capture even a sliver of that tortured-soul sports-movie's insight or visceral power.
A starchy, flavorless pudding.
At times, the film's lyrical drift shades into incoherence, spackled with globs of free-floating voiceover and Larry Clark-like indolent moments.
Without a source as rich as Jane Austen to draw on, Cheerful Weather feels incomplete, caroming off previous stories without forging its own way.
Date works best as a collection of winsome, unconnected vignettes; its ideal distribution model would be piece by piece on YouTube.
It's hard to imagine how someone could study this case for so long and yet miss its most critical lesson.
Barbara is Hoss' fifth film with Petzold, and the movie rests on the depth and subtlety of their working relationship.
An engaging study of the disparate characters who are drawn to speak out when the authorities crack the whip.
It's a deeply confused movie, sometimes productively so.
In 49 Up, many of the series' subjects seemed to be just settling into their bliss; now they're committed to it, and the foreclosed possibilities that come alongside.
Unmistakably part of the director's canon, and just as unmistakably a minor addition to it.
movie_title: Happy People: A Year in the Taiga (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Feels like the product of an explosion at the Sundance factory: a rural setting here, a wisp of mildly quirky indie rock there.
The film's subject is almost too horrible to contemplate, but it finds a way to space out the blows without softening them.
Shot with tiny digital cameras to minimize the sense of intrusion, The End Of Love sometimes feels like a home movie, but that's also the source of its strength.
The only thing more tiresome than a gritty reboot of a TV series is a gritty reboot of an unfamiliar TV series.
Ruzowitzky may be an occasionally interesting visual stylist, but storytelling-wise, his second English-language effort couldn't be more stillborn.
It's no surprise that Upstream Color is a head-scratcher, but its untrammeled emotionalism comes as a shock to the senses.
With her performance as Tris Prior in Divergent, [Woodley] rescues and then raises up a film that could have been an utter disaster.

The first question to ask about Bad Company is why Anthony Hopkins is in it. We assume he had a bad run in the market or a costly divorce, because there is no earthly reason other than money why this distinguished actor would stoop so low.
This is gruesome, not gripping.
Raimi crafted a complicated hero who is a welcome relief from the usual two-dimensional offerings.
Neither the acting nor the script elevates the film above a ham-fisted morality play dripping with earnestness.
The documentary is simple and strong and small. Its grit lifts it above its mechanical shortcomings.
City by the Sea begins life in great health only to be strangled in its crib by bad writing.
If this movie is uncharacteristically radiant (and, my, is it), then it's also aloof and unexpectedly ordinary.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A long, complicated affair that has its moments but suffers from an overwrought plot.
If there's no art here, it's still a good yarn -- which is nothing to sneeze at these days.
In terms of sheer entertainment, The Cloverfield Paradox is a joy.
Admirably intense, but the film lacks focus.

The title says it all. Seemingly eager to show us that they're still pranksters rather than players, the post-Oscar Coens whip up a screwball soufflé that only the perverse will ponder at length. Snappy, snarky and full of big stars being very, very silly

A searing, epic vision of a city in the grip of gangland terror. The multi-stranded plot takes some unpacking, but the characters, camerawork and unflinching realism compel like a gun to the head. The best gangster saga since City Of God.
The original books appeal to generations of readers, but this flick's strictly for tweens and slumming homage-spotters.

It doesn't have the emotion or tenderness of Burstein's American Teen, and where the LA Times predicted the next (500) Days Of Summer, we're left instead with a bog-standard chick-flick, as light and superficial as you'd usually expect.
Buried is a truly compelling, novel and refreshing experience. It's a high concept film that stretches its idea over the duration of 90 minutes with ease.

At times I'm Still Here is as ridiculous as Borat, which certainly adds weight to the naysayers' arguments, and yet even through the multiple shots of male nudity, drug taking and human desecration, everything feels organic.

It should be an electrifying tale of love and loss set against the turbulent economic crash of 2008, but instead there's a whole lot of smoke without real fire, and while it's entertaining enough, you'll undoubtedly still leave the cinema disappointed.

If you look hard enough, certainly there are problems to find with Despicable Me, but it's an enjoyable and fun Sunday afternoon movie, primed for multiple viewings even if you don't get anything else out of it the second and third times around.

Despite all of the betrayal, court cases and double crossing, let's be honest, no-one really cares about the founding of Facebook, but in the hands of David Fincher, however, The Social Network is something of a masterpiece.
On the surface a beautiful film. But those looking for some hidden spiritual meaning be warned - Eat Pray Love doesn't go that deep.
There is undoubted potential in director Ruben Östlund, and on Involuntary, he revels in the awkward atmosphere created between every day folk, it just doesn't feel like the finished product yet.

Let Me In is a very accomplished thriller, perfectly brooding and moody without ever going over the top. Is it better than Let The Right One In? It doesn't matter, the film does more than enough to stand on its own two feet.
Jason Bateman plays the reserved guy we're used to by now, but he has so much charisma his character Wally is effortlessly watchable, and the best thing about the film.

Though Paranormal Activity 2 doesn't quite have the shock value or surprise nature of the first film, it's a fitting sequel and close and respectfully builds on Peli's original, for which kudos should certainly be paid to studio Paramount.
Guys certainly shouldn't throw their dignity out of the window to go see it alone, but if their girlfriends are dragging them along, they might just enjoy it a lot more than expected.
These are very assured strides into the mainstream from director Daniel Stamm, and he's certainly guaranteed himself a few enticing offers when the time for his next film comes around.
Salt is a good bet for 100 minutes of fun but it doesn't have the spark, originality or true thrills of something like Enemy Of The State or the Bourne series.
An exhibition in arthouse for arthouse's sake, Certified Copy doesn't do enough to draw a second glance from lovers of the movement nor mainstream cinemagoers alike.
This is one of the best comedies of the summer, though perhaps that says more about the quality of films in 2010 than The Other Guys itself.
The film feels bland and unadventurous, quite the opposite of what you need for a cross-country trail that can throw up so many possibilities. From top to bottom, it feels thoroughly mediocre.

Due Date follows all of the classic story twists you'd associate with the sub-genre; they get arrested, they get drunk, they get high, and they destroy their car, but never are these shocking moments ever actually surprising.
You could do worse with young kids, and they'll romp along with Marmaduke's throwaway adventures, it's just there's much better stuff out there that will entertain viewers above the age of 10 too.
If you can ignore what is an undoubted handful of shame thrown upon yourself by checking this film out, you'll have a great time along the way.
Down Terrace doesn't just feel like the work of a first-time filmmaker, but that of someone who's never before thought of making movies.
Such a bland and lifeless experience even the most ardent of Scott Sanders or Michael Jai White fans will do well to not grow bored before the end.
Not quite the masterpiece you might expect but you can certainly see why the Academy fell head over heels for The Secret In Their Eyes.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Last Airbender completes writer/co-producer/director M. Night Shyamalan's fall from grace; once regarded as the most exciting talent in film, he now sits pretty as the laughing stock of Hollywood.
Though Predators isn't quite as well put together as the original film, nor do the sequences offer the same sustained threat, it's still enough to get your adrenaline flowing.

'Horror romp' would be an apt description of the 90 minute story, only with the original concept detailed as a burglar breaking into a serial killer's home, it's difficult not to think what might have been.
There's no life to the film, no spark, and more importantly no real reason for this fourth outing to have ever been made.

A little more focussed than the first, but without as strong themes or plot, The Girl Who Plays With Fire doesn't top The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo but it's a solid sequel that you will draw you back once again for the third film.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Unstoppable isn't a bad film per-se, but it's a by the numbers thriller that isn't remotely thrilling, and will do very well indeed to make back its remarkable $100m budget.
For it's hard work, sadly the film's two heartfelt, emotional scenes are wholly undermined by some awful soundtracking.
Based on a play, and adapted by the original playwright, sadly the narrative hasn't translated at all well and the structure feels out of place.
A fun movie that you can lose yourself in for a little over 100 minutes and get a thrill and laugh or two along the way.

From the pen newcomer Kyle Killen, creator of the brilliant, but instantaneously cancelled, Lone Star, it reeks of promise but vast inexperience, while Jodie Foster perhaps could have helmed the narrative better too.
"It happened again." That's the opening gambit of The Hangover: Part II, but sadly the same can be said of the franchise.

I'm not asking for Citizen Kane here, but just a wisp of expansion to the characters, an actual narrative that the film can walk down, or just some sort of ambition to the whole project would not have gone amiss.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Super 8 is a complex movie about family issues, young love and friendship, that just happens to have a strange monster running around in the background.

Outside The Law is a fairly run of the mill slice of historical action/crime-drama, but ironically one that has just enough story to sustain your attention, but all too little historical fact to truly deserve your it to begin with.
Mother's Day is a very competent, home-invasion thriller, glossy to the eye, if too bloody once it gets into its rhythm.
A very strong British monster movie and a great idea, and ode to South London, to base it all in a council block.
Cedar Rapids can't decide if it wants to be an R-rated romp or much sweeter comedy-drama, and in the end, falls inadequately between the two.
If you go along with the silliness in the film and you'll have fun, but Your Highness is still very hit and miss.
Fast And Furious 5 is far, far from a classic, it's not even the best in the series, but it'll spin two hours by with ease and some excitement along the way, even as absurd and silly as it may be.
Arthur could have been a caring and heartfelt comedy, but the tone is mixed, and the narrative missteps on all the wrong notes.
The image of its heroine standing in silhouette in a doorway, unsure of whether to cross over, is quite simply the most iconic horror image of the year.
Nothing in this film really stands out, it's one big non-event, but that means at least it won't ruin the memory of Pooh for older eyes, it's far too bland to do that.
We're left with a week of two guys not even trying to make the most of their freedom, and though that alone doesn't make for enough of a movie, in Hall Pass, that's all you're going to get.
Maybe the next one will be a return to form for the living legend, and hey, at the rate Allen is churning them out, one of them has to be good, right?
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully and carefully crafted, though the chapter titles are a little too much, elsewhere Submarine is 'indie' and alternative on all the right beats
Could have been put together in a much snappier way, with a hugely convoluted opening certainly not helping The Rite's uneven pace.
Shakespeare is spinning in his grave.
So extensive is Unknown's pilfering of ideas from existing films that it has left itself exposed as a meagre mishmash that fails to excel in any particular department.
Yogi Bear barely raises a grin, it's only Miller and Daly's charisma and ad-lib that goes some way to saving it.
The story doesn't do anything near enough to keep you involved for the 88-minute runtime, aimlessly meandering forward without even a whiff of narrative structure.
No String Attached is a dismal start for 2011's casual sex comedies.
Radnor should be more than pleased with his film debut, and this is how rom-coms should be made, not like the hapless Hollywood offerings.
Hollywood gloss will paper over a few of The Dilemma's problems but you'll leave the cinema more feeling indifferent than anything else.

Featuring some enthralling performances from Murray, Spacek and last but by no means least the great Duvall, you might find yourself whimpering unexpectedly in this looming yet comical adaptation of a Tennessee fable.

If the action didn't work, it would be as forgettable as the film that spawned it. But Simon West's shiny and swift direction, inspired by Tony Scott sensationalism and invigorated by a Louisiana blues score, just about manages to grip.
The filmmakers and producers deserve great praise for their ambition and faith in a film that steps outside of the Hollywood comfort zone, even if the product doesn't have the execution to match.
A great evening's entertainment when you want to switch off and dip your head in some popcorn.
It's watchable, certainly, but it lacks anything to really draw you in and certainly won't blow you away like some of Chen Zhen's previous outings might.
movie_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The A-Team is a brainless action film, don't expect anything more or less, and that is both it's success and undoubted failings.
While all the right ingredients are there for Prince Of Persia, the end result is still far from a masterpiece.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Killers feels like the build-up of Mr And Mrs Smith, only that's the whole movie and the chronic lack of a third act when even the second act is wafer thin is almost unforgivable.
As remakes go, Last House On The Left is at least a decent addition to the 1972 classic.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It could have all been a lot worse and with some imaginative new Terminators, a great score some thrilling action set-plays, critics slating the film will be proven harsh as box office results and public opinion soon come in.
The Hangover doesn't contain the constant rip-roaring laughs the likes of Superbad or some of the Frat Pack's best.
It's frustrating that if Transformers 2 took itself a little more seriously, it might just have blown audiences away the same way the original did.
Only big fans of Cera and Black need catch this film, and even then, it's far from a must-see.
Public Enemies is an enjoyable experience but it feels like it could have been a whole lot more and another gangster classic.
For older viewers the jokes struggles to find a pay off and the frequent potty humour will even grow tiresome for the younger audience.
Another thoroughly engaging release from Fox Searchlight, the studio's indie releasing sidearm is rapidly becoming the saviour of an otherwise grossly mismanaged company.
G.I. Joe: Rise Of Cobra is a very throwaway experience, likely to be forgotten by the film world very quickly.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Aliens In The Attic might fall between a key audiences but will certainly provide a rip-roaring time for both tweens and younger kids, never mind the parents who are seemingly dragged along.
You might chuckle a couple of times, but it is literally a couple, and that's nowhere near enough humour, especially for kids.
Despite some of the scenes dragging on too long, Inglourious Basterds is still a lot of fun, altering history for the better as the Nazis feel the force of redemption.

One of the few must watches of the year so far, and certainly one of the most intelligent offerings, The Hurt Locker would likely already be boasting a masterpiece label had it been from a high profile director or studio.
Drag Me To Hell is the thrill ride Sam Raimi should be making year-on-year, not another cash cow hapless Spider-Man film.
Cloudy With A Chance Of Meatballs might not be as charming or heartfelt as anything from Pixar film, but bar Up, it's the best animated film of the year so far.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: You won't be missing anything spectacular if you don't catch The Descent: Part 2, for horror fans and those who enjoyed the original, however, it's definitely worth a go.
Avatar spans genres and will truly please all generations of a family with perfect pacing that makes the 162 minute running time feel like a breeze.
The Oscar talk surrounding It's Complicated is some way off, it's not a bad film, but it's certainly nothing to get excited about.
Set in Ireland, it feels very much an Irish film and perhaps the closed tone of the film makes it a little inaccessible.
Whip It follows the classic follows the classic tropes of any indie coming-of-age film, big game showdown et al, but does it all so well you'll be instantly charmed.
Zombieland will undoubtedly become the new zombie-comedy cult classic for the current generation.
Echoing the tone of a wicked childhood nightmare, Triangle suggests big things are back on the horizon for Christopher Smith, even if he hasn't quite hit a home run just yet.
Couples Retreat is a lazy, unimaginative comedy that, with the talent on show, should have been a whole lot more than another boring rom-com to throw on the pile.
The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard is an entirely throwaway experience that doesn't offer anything vaguely witty or clever. Look elsewhere to satisfy your comedy needs.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: I can't claim to have seen every terrible film in cinematic history, but in my fairly extensive watchography, 2012 is certainly in the top 5 worst ever.
There are plenty of moments of fun and excitement, but the extent to which the film drags its heels in between, is ultimately its undoing.
Ever since early footage screened at Comic-Con last year, the buzz surrounding Kick-Ass has been building to fever-pitch; for once, it's thoroughly deserved, and then some.

If Transformers 3 was produced purely to be an expose of what you can do with CGI in the modern era, it'd get full marks. It's truly is the ultimate showreel for Industrial Light & Magic. But it's meant to be a film, and sadly it's not very good at that.
Don't be surprised if Up is sitting pretty atop our top 10 films of the year list come the New Year.
Somehow J.J. Abrams has managed to make Star Trek cool again, with a fresh and fast-paced, action-packed thrill ride that both new and old fans can lavishly enjoy.
His directorial debut is a remarkably deep and rich film, somewhat daunting upon first showing, challenging the audience to take in this complex movie.
Angels & Demons isn't the complete shambles a lot of people wanted it to be. But then that probably isn't the greatest endorsement either.
If you're a fan of the SNL sketch, you'll like what you see here, though newcomers might be left asking why they bothered to adapt it for the big screen at all.

The direction from first-timer Jim Field Smith is bland and without character, and you feel that if someone with more confidence and a swagger to their filmmaking had been in charge we'd have seen something that stepped beyond cinematic mediocrity

From what is a fairly big name cast, LaBute gets absolutely nothing out of them, and the narrative is similarly choppy and disjointed. Tracy Morgan is the only actor to come out of the film without his career taking a hit.
Cop Out is clichéd but just about gets away with it despite some lacklustre gags along the way.
Entirely devoid of personality, music video director Samuel Bayer is unable to handle the flow of a feature film, stuttering from dream sequence to dream sequence without cohesion.

Iron Man 2 might not have the power or tone of the recent Batman film, but that's not what the filmmakers are after, and crafting thrill ride that's so easy and accessible to take in, it'll be tough to find a more fun way to spend a couple of hours.
Without any real character development, by the time the closing credits draw in, you won't care less about any of the characters, which for a film with a plot so linear, is a fatal flaw.
Date Night isn't a comedy classic but it is undeniably a lot of fun, and easily hits the laugh quota.
Though far from Studio Ghibli's best film, Ponyo is still a magical experience.
Makes early claims for the best comedy of 2010.
Dalston's answer to American Psycho, and it's almost every bit as good.
Astro Boy is one film unlikely to be given the sequels its good name previously deserved.
With the lack of energy infused in the film, it's hard to get truly embroiled in the conspiracy but that doesn't mean Edge Of Darkness is a complete failure.
Despite the honest, authentic ideals, Disney's traditional animation studios can't cope with the imagination or storytelling of their colleagues, Pixar.
Throwaway fun at some points of the film, but on the whole it's simply very frustrating.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Exam can't follow through on its ideas and premise.
The final damning verdict left by the American box office, whom far from raced out to see it, meaning takings of 8m leave Punisher: War Zone the lowest grossing Marvel adaptation to date.

If you are willing to turn your brain off, Fisher makes the film very watchable, but it's core message over materialism and financial stupidity are confused and the film lacks just that few more laughs to tip it above mediocrity.
Set and filmed on location in bustling Hong Kong, the tight urban street and winding alleyways suit the film perfectly, but this is not enough to save Push from the Oscar season garbage dump.
Doesn't offer anything new but it is an ample addition to the comedy genre, and after a mostly rip-roaring 91 minutes, you'll understand how the film did so well in America.
The one dimensional narrative struggles to hit home.
At last, State Of Play is an example of a Hollywood refresh that not only stand up to the source, but builds upon it.
Here's hoping this is the last, but after the huge amount of money it has taken already in the States, don't be surprised to see a 5th.
Accessible even for those not interested in politics, In The Loop is easily the funniest film of the year so far, and to boot, one of the most intelligent.
Hopefully writers Neustadter and Weber have already got another project in the works.
Reported to be the one thing missing in-part from the leaked workprint, sadly many of the special effects in X-Men Origins: Wolverine are somewhat sub-standard.
Doesn't have the originality of the first film and feels a little boring as such.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Awaydays comes close to being lumped in with every other British indie but the excellent production quality pull it through and director Pat Holden is left with another promising, if flawed, adventure.
Under-exploring the big reveal of the murderer and dragging the set plays out a little too long, Tormented's early promise fails to pull home.
Managing to create real moments of suspense, a hugely powerful emotional sequence towards the end is testament to the relationships we've built up with this bunch of toys.
It's hugely sad that the Emeryville studio have turned in their first dud but the stark reality is that Cars 2 really offers very little for neither kids nor adults.
This 2010 update doesn't have the social commentary of Romero's film, but for 101 minutes of action-packed, edge of your seat stuff, that's not necessarily a bad thing.
Mike Mills' new film has all the caricatures of an 'indie' production but the skilled filmmaker knows how to keep each just in check, and hold firm to a central narrative.
It seems like all the summ er blockbusters this year are coming in spring, but Days of Future Past will surely hold up as one of the year's best.
A one-off masterpiece, the likes of which has never been done before, and will never be done again.
The film has lost its soul, its life sapped by the filmmaker's arduous style, and its a great disappointment because there are definitely still legs in the central idea.
As Ferrera runs out of reported events to hang his story on, he spirals out of control into a dull and obvious climax.
Before I Disappear shows a lot of promise for the cast and actor/writer/director Christensen.
Guns and explosions aren't that exciting when the plot hasn't sucked you in, and lacking the imaginative, spunky spirit of the original, Machete Kills just feels so much more laboured.
An honest tale of love and desperation from a couple making ends meet, Ain't Them Bodies Saints might just have been Lowery's audition for the big leagues. And he nailed it.

I will concede that there were 3 scenes which pulled something between a chortle and a guffaw from me, but by that time they came along, my face had already set into such a stony grimace that smiling genuinely hurt.

It would have been nice to have seen more of the rest of the cast, particularly the other members of the news team, but Ferrell does a great job of carrying what ends up being a fairly lengthy main narrative.
An engaging and well executed turn from the accomplished Ozon.
Ultimately Parkland is not thought-provoking, inspiring or even brave enough to be offensive, but it does raise some interesting scenarios and is full of some very solid acting.
It rattles along at a slick pace and the final sequence is everything you could want from a closing crescendo.
You get the feeling that there's an extremely interesting story unfolding, but we're constantly on the periphery and there's not nearly enough substance to sink your teeth into.
Next Goal Wins is a classic underdog story, but it is entirely original.
There are moments of laugh out loud comedy mixed in with grim scenes of graphic violence, all punctuated by some of the most fantastically sweary tirades you're likely to hear this year.
Even if it's flawed by a few obvious clichés, Love Is All You Need still comes highly recommended.

If you can look beyond Harmony Korine's misogynistic, uncomfortably leering view of the women in his film, there is some stuff to enjoy, though the film is held back by an unfortunate lack of substance.
A complex, breakneck and stirring modern thriller, superb in both execution and conceptual ideas even if it is a little over-indulgent.
Jack The Giant Slayer is an entertaining family adventure, with moments of tension and humour in equal measure.
The natural charisma of the two leads is about the only thing that saves Identity Thief; it's a very generic, very lazy Hollywood comedy.

Hot properties John Francis Daley and Jonathan Goldstein (Horrible Bosses) penned the script, and while it's another effort which lacks depth and real emotional involvement, they're certainly proving themselves as dependable, if not exceptional, talents.
Welcome To The Punch should feel a little grander, like it's on a bigger scale to match the wide-ranging plot.
The Iceman is dark and gritty but there's not enough excitement or tension to really pull you in.
Brutal, shocking and powerful in all the right ways, Diaz: Don't Clean Up This Blood is a visceral flood, pushing the limits to get across the extreme nature of the police brutality.
movie_title: Diaz: Don't Clean Up This Blood (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There was barely enough depth to these characters to pull us through the first 100 minutes, now five hours later they've become thoroughly boring.
A satisfying next step in a series which brings out the little boy and his Hot Wheels cars in all of us.
The Kings Of Summer is a brilliant, endearing and engaging coming of age comedy, not only the funniest film of the year, but also the best film of the year to date.

Writer/director Stu Zicherman's last work in Hollywood was co-writing Jennifer Garner superhero movie Elektra, so A.C.O.D. is quite at least a big step in the right direction, but I hope there's a little more craft and a little more bite on the next film.

Prince Avalanche is a slow burn and it does grow on you over time, but despite the central pair sharing undoubted chemistry, the movie's dialogue isn't as riveting as it needed to be and it inevitably feels a little flat.
In his almost documentary style of filmmaking, Lindholm has achieved an impressive sense of realism and you can certainly see why the film has attracted a lot of attention on the festival circuit.
Though the stellar acting talent do much to bring this amazing true story to life, Pioneer struggles to ever leave you on the edge of your seat.
With the film feeling so remarkably slapdash, it is a big step down Vigalondo's previous work, and a hugely disappointing English language debut.
Compared to Pixar's recent masterpiece Coco, so full of life, imagination and eccentricity, Early Man is middling, it's grey vs. technicolour.

The remarkable story of one of the most influential illegal drug organisations you've never heard of, Orange Sunshine is William A. Kirkley's ground-breaking documentary about hippie group, the Brotherhood of Eternal Love.
With Studio Ghibli in an indefinite haitus, we must cherish their beloved films, and this is one of the very best.
There is obvious talent in the storytelling but at times the reserved style of filmmaking feels televisual and there 's no spark to really get the film going.
I Dream Too Much means well but it can't move beyond its televisual a esthetic and a bland plot that doesn't really go anywhere.
The film is gently funny, if a bit too slow, but the bizarro story line takes it to unexpected places and doing something different in the film industry right now is a much needed thing.

Perhaps in other hands Fresno could have been a hilarious dark comedy , but instead Jamie Babbit and Karey Dornetto have made a chronically unfunny farce, harsh and offensive in its tone, inexcusably laughing at those who are worse off than themselves.
It's not as sharp or witty as you'd expect from a Duplass Brothers product ion but Adult Beginners is still another decent outing in their ever-impressive canon.
Gary Gardner is able to build real tension, filming the actors up close and get right in the face of action. There's definitely enough here to be excited for more of his work in the future.

Winter does a great job of delving into the underworld of the internet and the intricacies of the Silk Road case, it's just a shame it's not a more rounded view, as you can't help but feel there's another side to the case you're not being told about.

Hannah Fidell has quickly become one of the faces to watch in independent film, her naturalistic style of filmmaking and ability to get the best of our her actors and shepherd improvised scenes creates characters and movies you want to root for.

Manglehorn is an intriguing film, or at least it should have been. David Gordon Green's latest is unfortunatel y passive, there might be depths to explore on a second or third watch, but I struggled to make it through the first.

Lost River is a hugel y impressive debut, even if it is ultimately flawed. It feels like a first feature, and that's OK, and displays an art and eye from Gosling you might not have thought he possessed.
There are some similarities to the perpetual failings of the characters in Frances Ha, and this movie equally fails to charm.
Bone In The Throat isn't short on high-octane moments or a thrilling climax, but it is the tension of every one-to-one relationship that makes the film tick.
It hopes to riff off the classic era of slasher films, but unfortunately The Final Girls only ends up adding to the clichés.
This is a film that plays up to the vapidity of starry circles and embraces the characters' devil-may-care attitude as an irresponsible dream.
It feels like Lionsgate are killing time rather than driving forward, so hopefully the long-term success of the franchise isn't harmed by a short-term money grab.
The feeling upon the closing credits is one of relief; with the plot nicely tied up, hopefully Shawn Levy gets the hint and finally moves on to try new things with his career.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The action and chase sequences are visceral and triumphant but Furious 7 is undone by a misogynistic streak that runs all the way through the movie and director James Wan's relentless objectification of its female characters.
The film is persistently misogynistic and degrading towards women, racist at times, and Jennifer Aniston's character fantasying about two 14-year-old boys having sex is completely inappropriate.
Co-directors Iain Forsyth and Jane Pollard have put together an enigmatic piece.
Gone Girl is a dark and intelligent thriller that plays to Fincher's magnetising style, the two really are a match made in heaven.
From the outside That Awkward Moment looks like a typical, throwaway comedy but it has heart and an indie spirit that turn it into something altogether different, something that deserves to be seen.
Chef is a funny and exciting road trip movie and, while not downgrading the success he's had with his two Iron Man films, is Favreau's best film for years.
The opening ad closing 20 minutes prove difficult but what comes in between is exciting and unexpected, symbolising the excitement and difficulty of discovering who you are.
Sharply written with some great dialogue and a magnificent and captivating performance from lead Angus Sampson.
It's a bizarre and surprisingly clever concept that really makes the most of it for a lot of laughs.
The Little Death pushes the boundaries but isn't offensive, and at times the comedy really works.
If action B-movies are your thing then this is just about worth searching out.

Dangerously ignorant and inaccurate on the subject of diabetes, Hansel and Gretel should be disregarded at all costs, and the filmmakers really ashamed they put something so irresponsible on the big screen.
Kids will enjoy Hotel Transylvania, and it won't bore the socks off adults too.
Brad Pitt and Matt Damon should have known better

What the film boast in charm and exuberance, it sadly lacks in emotional core, and while there isn't really any depth to the bonds formed over the 90 minutes, it's still a great family-friendly action-comedy.
Though you're expecting the predictable ending, the finale, and what goes on before it, feels phoney and contrived, while a vulgar mean streak throughout only further puts you off.
Not exploring the Merry Pranksters wider cultural influence and historical significance is a great misstep.
Without the ambition to ever do anything more, Justice is a lacklustre, low-grade thriller that you'd be disappointed by had it not set its standards so cripplingly low.
An endearing tale of family, friendship and fighting for what you believe in.
Considering that the lead character is near naked for almost half the film, it's remarkable just how unprovocative Julia Leigh's debut Sleeping Beauty feels.
It's hugely impressive that with no redemption in sight, you'll still remain glued to the screen until the bitter end.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: In the end it feels a little like a Fincher wannabee, rather than boasting its an identity in itself.
There are some films so bad, they don't warrant a review. This is one of them.
At not a single point in this movie is anyone abducted.
Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark is all-encapsulatingly scary, but not perhaps in the way you might have expected.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The plot could have great weight but it never makes use of it, while the revelations explored in the past, aren't followed through in the present.
Without the other Earth playing a key role in the story, what's left is a generic tale of uninteresting characters trading fairly laboured dialogue.
Swapping out the usual relationship tangle for a cancer-centric plot, 50/50 feels like this year's (500) Days Of Summer.
The film treats the audience with intelligence; it doesn't lay everything out and instead leaves you to do a little legwork too.
This is a smart, complex and intelligent movie, from a filmmaker at the top of his game. Banderas delivers a cultured performance, though really the full ensemble deserve great credit.

The story is told in a very episodic manner, but Lone Scherfig crafts it well and the film is well edited to keep it feeling as one. It feels exciting and unexpected, even though you know really it never is.

A link into the earlier films at the close of 5 is nice, but adds little overall, and though it might be fun with a bunch of friends on a Friday night, hopefully this is the end for what has become a very tired franchise.

The Art Of Getting By is not the horror show some US critics might have you believe; there are a lot of problems, but it's more than possible to look beyond them and find the still plentiful moments of quality and endearment beneath.
Even Platinum Dunes make better remakes than this.
A hitman film with no energy, no pace, and so without a compelling narrative it relies on gore-hungry murders to keep your eyes on the screen. And it's not even very good at them.
In acts two and three it becomes more predictable in each of the ideals it berates in act one, and not in a clever or ironic way; Katherine Heigl may as well have taken on the lead role.
Always unlikely to repeat the breakout success of Zombieland, 30 Minutes Or Less attempts but lacks the wit and surprise of the director's last film
Despite a lack of conviction in the script, Caesar's origin is still adequately set, so here's hoping what will follow has a little more to grab your attention.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: I couldn't help but wonder who this weird romantic/animal comedy was aimed at when the film gets suffocated by a tedious love chasing travesty that would confuse kids and bore the hell out of enduring adults.
What it could have been is there for all to see, but Sarah's Key doesn't come close to being compelling enough, as it's only real positive is a great performance from a star of the future young girl.
A popcorn comedy you shouldn't be ashamed of wanting to see.

Crazy, Stupid, Love sees directors John Requa and Glenn Ficarra very quickly building a name for themselves, able to again craft an honest film that, up until the very end, flows naturally and with great confidence.
The dialogue isn't snappy while the physical comedy is predictable
The narrative drives forward for a powerful 94-minute runtime but it leaves little opportunity to really invest in what's going on.
Most of the talent look embarrassed to be on screen
The hit and miss nature of Ruby Sparks is a surprise given it's from the same duo that brought us Little Miss Sunshine.
Actively frustrating and a tedious experience to endure.

A lack of originality does hold the film back, but with decent work behind the camera and a breakneck finale, Paranormal Activity 4 is still a solid watch if you've an evening spare, or horror film night coming up.
The sky's the limit for Ben Affleck right now, and its nothing less than he deserves.
Another notch on Tom Cruise's action hero belt and demonstrates why he is still one the most bankable action men in Hollywood
The morals of the story don't come through, while the film's extensive metaphors are belatedly rammed down your throat like a get out of jail free card.

Director Ben Wheatley's uncompromising style fits the deadpan humour perfectly but despite the movie's comic tones, the characters are still so unappealing that the movie's overall nature proves restrictive.
Thanks to the muddled plot motivations Tower Block really struggles in the final third.
If only the movie didn't almost glamorise Bourdin's action, they'd have been onto a real masterpiece.
Starring famous East End faces, the likes of Alan Ford are meant to bring a grit and X factor to the film but their catchphrases are nothing more than a cliché.
One of the standout movies of the year, never mind the summer.
Consider this another step on Josh Radnor's ascendancy into filmmaking.
Engaging and sensitive
A heartfelt romantic-comedy that turns a predictable story into a genuinely enjoyable adventure.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Apparently Fox are making a fifth, and people wonder what's pushing originality out of Hollywood.
Chronically let down by a lack of character development, with no spark at the off to get the whole thing rolling.
A marvellous magical adventure, that'll perhaps stand the test of time even better than some of Pixar's movies we right now call classics.
With a stuttering story, some elements of the narrative struggle to hit home but Prometheus is still generally a success.
Re-watch the teaser trailer, skip the final production.
A less than subtle attempt to get him [Gibson] back to the renegade action star roles with which he made his name.
It's a while since anyone has made a film like this, and it'll probably be longer until we get another, so even if Stillman isn't your cup of tea, you should try to savour Damsels while it lasts.
Slo-mo action at every turn probably doesn't help but at least it's not the total horror show it could have been.

While the film struggles at the start as Tatum and Hill share little chemistry, they improve minute by minute and are one of the shining lights by the end, their journey boasting a surprising emotional pull.
It was right the Avengers shouldn't gel right at once, but how that get-to-know-you period is played out in the script gets massively out of hand.
The story of how Paige and Leo met is riddled with clichés
One For The Money is a paint-by-numbers chick-flick that'll make you laugh a few times but won't particularly enamour.
A ridiculous plot is punctuated by out of place action scenes and a chronic lack of humour

The film fails to explore each's new partners, and while leaving the focus on the central relationship isn't always a bad thing, when main duo fail to captivate in their own right, it feels a misstep not to have expanded the narrative.
Haywire feels like a lot of people aimlessly running around for 90 minutes, kicking each other to the whimsical jazz score.

Pretty much an open goal given the inevitable payoff that concluding a story some seven films in the making was always going to bring, director David Yates though has helmed a very impressive film, and the best of the whole series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Chris Columbus was a safe choice behind the lens, and he doesn't throw up any surprises. Columbus brings a measured approach that works on the whole, delivering the expected mix of set-ups, set-pieces and edge of your seat showdowns.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)
